questions.text: While doing fundoplication for GERD, the surgeon was demonstrating his assistant the maneuver shown in the figure. What is this called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Shoe shine maneuver. Explanation: Shoe shine maneuver is a specific step during Nissen fundoplication, a surgical procedure used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). During this maneuver, the fundus (upper part of the stomach) is passed behind the esophagus and manipulated back and forth — resembling the motion of shining a shoe. This movement ensures that the wrap (fundoplication) is not too tight and that there is sufficient mobility and length of the gastric fundus to create a tension-free 360° wrap around the lower esophagus. It is a critical technique to prevent postoperative complications like dysphagia due to an overly tight wrap. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Heaney Maneuver This maneuver is unrelated to fundoplication. It is used in hepatic surgery to control bleeding — specifically involving clamping of the suprahepatic and infrahepatic segments of the inferior vena cava and combining with a Pringle maneuver to temporarily reduce hepatic blood flow. C. Pringle Maneuver The Pringle maneuver is used to control hepatic hemorrhage during liver surgery or trauma. It involves occluding the hepatoduodenal ligament (which contains the portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile duct) to reduce bleeding from the liver. It has no role in fundoplication. D. Heimlich Maneuver The Heimlich maneuver is a first-aid procedure for relieving choking by applying abdominal thrusts to expel a foreign body from the airway. It is unrelated to any surgical procedure, including fundoplication.

questions.text: Patient present with Halitosis and a swelling in the lateral aspect of neck, Which on pressing gives rise to a regurgitant air sound. Barium image is shown. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pharyngeal pouch/Zenker’s diverticulum. Explanation: Zenker’s diverticulum, also known as a pharyngeal pouch, is a pulsion-type false diverticulum that occurs through Killian’s dehiscence — an area of weakness between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles of the inferior pharyngeal constrictor. It typically presents in elderly patients and is characterized by halitosis (bad breath) due to retained food in the pouch, dysphagia, and a swelling in the lateral neck that may gurgle or produce a regurgitant air sound when pressed. On barium swallow imaging, it appears as a posterior outpouching from the pharyngoesophageal junction. The gold standard for diagnosis is a barium swallow, and the treatment is surgical, often involving diverticulectomy and cricopharyngotomy. Incorrect Options: A. Laryngocele Laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the laryngeal saccule that protrudes through the thyrohyoid membrane. It may present as a lateral neck swelling that increases with Valsalva (e.g., blowing or coughing) and is often associated with chronic straining or playing wind instruments. However, halitosis is not a feature, and it does not produce a regurgitant air sound on pressure. B. Dysphagia Lusoria This is caused by an aberrant right subclavian artery compressing the esophagus from behind. It presents with dysphagia, especially to solids, but does not cause halitosis or neck swelling. On barium swallow, it shows a posterior indentation of the esophagus, not a pouch. D. Schatzki Ring A Schatzki ring is a thin, circumferential mucosal ring at the squamocolumnar junction in the distal esophagus. It typically causes intermittent dysphagia to solids, particularly when eating quickly or large meals. It does not cause halitosis, neck swelling, or regurgitant air sounds. It appears as a thin concentric ring on barium swallow imaging.

questions.text: Dohlman’s procedure is used for?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Zenker’s diverticulum. Explanation: Dohlman’s procedure is an endoscopic treatment specifically used for Zenker’s diverticulum, a pulsion-type pharyngeal pouch that forms through Killian’s dehiscence — a weak area between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus muscles. The Dohlman’s technique involves endoscopic electrocauterization or laser division of the cricopharyngeal muscle, which allows the pouch to empty more effectively into the esophagus. This procedure is minimally invasive and preferred in elderly patients or those unfit for open surgery. It alleviates symptoms like dysphagia, regurgitation, and halitosis by removing the functional obstruction at the upper esophageal sphincter. Incorrect Options: A. Meckel’s diverticulum Meckel’s diverticulum is a congenital true diverticulum located on the antimesenteric border of the ileum. It often presents with painless lower GI bleeding in children. The treatment is surgical diverticulectomy, not Dohlman’s procedure. C. Dermatomyositis Dermatomyositis is an inflammatory myopathy characterized by muscle weakness and skin manifestations like heliotrope rash and Gottron’s papules. The treatment is medical, typically involving corticosteroids and immunosuppressive agents — not surgical interventions like Dohlman’s. D. Menetrier’s disease This is a rare hypertrophic gastropathy characterized by enlarged gastric rugal folds, protein loss, and hypoproteinemia. Treatment may involve medical therapy or gastrectomy, but it is unrelated to Zenker’s diverticulum and not treated with Dohlman’s procedure.

questions.text: A middle aged man complains of upper abdominal pain after a heavy meal. There is tenderness in the upper abdomen and on X ray widening of the mediastinum is seen with pneumo-mediastinum. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus. Explanation: Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave’s syndrome, is a life-threatening condition resulting from a sudden increase in intraesophageal pressure — typically due to forceful vomiting or retching — against a closed glottis. It commonly occurs in the distal third of the esophagus. Patients may present with severe upper abdominal or chest pain after a heavy meal or vomiting, along with signs like subcutaneous emphysema, pneumomediastinum, and widened mediastinum on chest X-ray. These radiographic findings are classic and result from air leaking into the mediastinum due to the esophageal rupture. Early diagnosis and management are critical to prevent mediastinitis and sepsis. Incorrect Options: B. Perforated peptic ulcer While a perforated peptic ulcer can present with sudden severe abdominal pain, it usually leads to free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum) rather than pneumomediastinum. Also, mediastinal widening is not a typical feature. C. Foreign body in esophagus A foreign body can cause discomfort or obstruction and, if neglected, may lead to perforation. However, in this scenario, there is no history of ingestion, and the acute onset after a heavy meal along with pneumomediastinum points more towards spontaneous esophageal rupture. D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla This condition is typically seen in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and may cause pneumothorax, not pneumomediastinum. Also, it usually presents with sudden chest pain and dyspnea, not abdominal pain after meals.

questions.text: A 45-years old man presented to the OPD with dysphagia to both solid and liquids. Esophageal manometry was performed – It revealed premature contraction with > 20% wet swallows and abnormally increased lower esophageal pressure of >450 mm Hg.The diagnosis is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Type 3 achalasia. Explanation: Type 3 achalasia, also called spastic or vigorous achalasia, is a subtype of achalasia characterized by abnormal lower esophageal sphincter (LES) relaxation along with premature or spastic contractions in the distal esophagus. On esophageal manometry, this presents as premature contractions with more than 20% of wet swallows, along with markedly elevated LES pressure — in this case, greater than 450 mm Hg. Clinically, patients present with dysphagia to both solids and liquids, chest pain, and regurgitation. Type 3 achalasia differs from the other types due to the presence of high-pressure, uncoordinated contractions, indicating a spastic motility disorder in addition to LES dysfunction. Incorrect Options: A. Type 1 achalasia Also known as classic achalasia, this type shows minimal or absent peristalsis and normal or mildly elevated LES pressure on manometry. There are no premature or spastic contractions, so it does not fit the manometric findings in this case. B. Type 2 achalasia This subtype shows pan-esophageal pressurization (simultaneous contraction of the entire esophagus) with >20% wet swallows, but without the high-amplitude or premature contractions seen in Type 3. LES pressure may be elevated, but not as markedly as in this case. Hence, the pattern described better fits Type 3. D. Jackhammer esophagus This is a hypercontractile esophageal disorder seen on manometry as very high-amplitude contractions, but with preserved LES relaxation. It is not associated with impaired LES relaxation, which is the hallmark of achalasia. Therefore, despite the high pressures, the LES dysfunction in this case rules out jackhammer esophagus.

questions.text: A 50 year old female presented with Dysphagia and chest pain. Barium image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES). Explanation: Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES) is a motility disorder of the esophagus characterized by intermittent chest pain and dysphagia to both solids and liquids. The key diagnostic feature is seen on barium swallow imaging, where the esophagus shows multiple simultaneous or uncoordinated contractions, producing a “corkscrew” or “rosary bead” appearance. This results from abnormal peristalsis in the mid and lower esophagus. DES can mimic angina due to chest pain and is confirmed with esophageal manometry, which shows uncoordinated, high-amplitude, non-peristaltic contractions. Incorrect Options: A. Carcinoma esophagus Carcinoma of the esophagus typically presents with progressive dysphagia (first to solids, then liquids) and weight loss. On barium swallow, it shows an irregular, narrowed, or "apple-core" lesion, not the smooth corkscrew pattern seen in DES. C. Esophageal web Esophageal webs are thin mucosal membranes that typically occur in the upper esophagus and are associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome. They cause dysphagia to solids but not liquids and appear on barium swallow as a focal constriction or shelf-like projection, not a corkscrew pattern. D. Achalasia cardia Achalasia cardia features impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter and absent peristalsis. On barium swallow, it presents with a “bird-beak” appearance of the distal esophagus, not the multiple simultaneous contractions seen in DES.

questions.text: Azygous preserving repair of TEF is done for following reason?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Decongest the anastomosis. Explanation: In tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) repair, particularly in neonates with esophageal atresia, preserving the azygous vein during surgery is considered beneficial. The azygous vein plays a key role in venous drainage from the thoracic structures, including the esophagus. When preserved, it helps to decongest the anastomotic site by maintaining optimal venous return, thereby reducing the risk of edema and promoting better healing of the esophageal anastomosis. Preservation of the azygous vein is associated with fewer complications such as anastomotic leak, stricture formation, and poor healing, and thus improves surgical outcomes. Incorrect Options: B. For feasibility of easy surgery In fact, preserving the azygous vein can make the procedure slightly more challenging, as it may obstruct the operative field. Division of the vein is often done to improve exposure, so preservation is not done for ease of surgery. C. To prevent recurrence TEF recurrence is usually due to factors such as tension on the anastomosis, infection, or poor tissue healing. Azygous vein preservation does not directly prevent recurrence of the fistula. D. None of the above This option is incorrect because Option A is clearly the correct and evidence-based rationale — azygous vein preservation improves venous drainage and supports better anastomotic healing.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of following Barium X-ray?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Carcinoma (CA) esophagus. Explanation: Carcinoma of the esophagus typically presents with progressive dysphagia (first to solids, then to liquids), weight loss, and sometimes chest discomfort. On barium swallow X-ray, the classic radiological sign is an irregular, narrowed segment of the esophageal lumen, often described as “shouldering,” “apple-core,” or “rat-tail” appearance, due to the invasive and ulcerative nature of the tumor. These irregular margins and asymmetrical narrowing help distinguish carcinoma from benign motility or inflammatory disorders. The barium image in this case shows such irregular narrowing, confirming the diagnosis of esophageal cancer. Incorrect Options: A. Achalasia Cardia Achalasia is a motility disorder with failure of LES relaxation and absent peristalsis. On barium swallow, it classically shows a smooth, tapering “bird-beak” appearance of the distal esophagus and proximal esophageal dilation — not irregular narrowing as seen in carcinoma. C. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome This syndrome is associated with upper esophageal webs, iron deficiency anemia, and dysphagia. On barium swallow, it shows a thin, shelf-like web or membrane in the upper esophagus. It doesn’t present as a long segment of irregular narrowing. D. GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease) GERD may show a normal barium swallow or nonspecific changes like feline esophagus (transient folds) or a small sliding hiatal hernia. It does not show irregular narrowing or mass lesions characteristic of carcinoma.

questions.text: A 4 year old boy presented to casualty by his mother with difficulty in swallowing.He was playing with coins.Chest x-ray is suggestive of following:-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oesophagus foreign body. Explanation: In children, accidental ingestion of foreign bodies like coins is common. When a foreign body is lodged in the esophagus, it typically appears as a circular (en face) radio-opaque shadow on an anteroposterior (AP) chest X-ray, because the esophagus lies in the midline and coins tend to orient with their flat surface in the coronal plane. This appearance is classic for a foreign body stuck in the upper esophagus, particularly at the level of the cricopharyngeus muscle, which is a common site of impaction. The child’s symptoms of difficulty swallowing and the clinical history of playing with coins support this diagnosis. Incorrect Options: B. Tracheal foreign body If a coin or other object is in the trachea, it usually appears as a linear shadow on the AP view and a circular shadow on the lateral view, due to the orientation within the airway. Tracheal foreign bodies often present with cough, stridor, or respiratory distress, rather than primarily dysphagia. C. Soft tissue neck calcification These calcifications, such as from lymph nodes or cartilage, tend to be smaller, irregular, and less dense than a coin, and do not correspond with a sudden onset of symptoms after playing with coins. They are usually incidental findings. D. Artifact Artifacts may simulate foreign bodies on imaging but often have unclear borders or variable positions on different views. In contrast, a true foreign body remains fixed in position and has a distinct, well-defined radio-opacity, as in this case.

choices.text: Hyperplastic change in the lining of oesophagus
Histology of the lesion shows mucus secreting goblet cells
Chronic GERD is a predisposing factor

questions.text: True about barett’s esophagus are all of the following except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hyperplastic change in the lining of oesophagus. Explanation: Barrett’s esophagus is a premalignant condition in which the normal squamous epithelium of the distal esophagus is replaced by intestinal-type columnar epithelium with mucus-secreting goblet cells — a process called intestinal metaplasia, not hyperplasia. This metaplastic change occurs as an adaptive response to chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It increases the risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma. Therefore, Option A is incorrect because the change is metaplastic, not hyperplastic. Incorrect Options: B. Patient is usually asymptomatic This is true. Barrett’s esophagus is often detected incidentally during endoscopy for GERD symptoms. Many patients do not have any specific symptoms beyond those already attributed to reflux. C. Histology of the lesion shows mucus secreting goblet cells This is true and a key diagnostic criterion. The presence of intestinal-type goblet cells in biopsies from the esophagus confirms the diagnosis of Barrett’s esophagus. D. Chronic GERD is a predisposing factor This is also true. Chronic acid reflux is the most important risk factor for Barrett’s esophagus. Longstanding GERD leads to repetitive injury and repair in the esophageal lining, which promotes metaplastic transformation.

questions.text: Serpiginous ulcer in distal esophagus is caused by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CMV (Cytomegalovirus). CMV is a common cause of serpiginous ulcers in the distal esophagus, especially in immunocompromised patients, such as those with HIV/AIDS or those who have undergone organ transplantation. CMV causes characteristic deep, serpentine-shaped ulcers that have a "snake-like" appearance. The virus can invade the esophagus and lead to ulceration, which is often seen as part of a broader systemic infection. CMV esophagitis is diagnosed by identifying inclusion bodies in the esophageal cells on biopsy or through PCR testing. Incorrect Responses: B. Herpes: While Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) can cause esophagitis, it usually leads to multiple small, punched-out ulcers, unlike the serpiginous ulcers seen in CMV infection. HSV is more likely to cause esophageal lesions that are discrete and round, not serpentine. C. Pills: Pill-induced esophagitis can occur when medications, especially large or poorly swallowed pills, get stuck in the esophagus and cause localized irritation or ulceration. This condition is typically seen with abrupt-onset, isolated, or shallow ulcers. However, it does not present as serpiginous ulcers, which are more characteristic of viral infections like CMV. D. Corrosive: Corrosive injury to the esophagus (from ingestion of caustic substances) can cause significant tissue damage, but the ulcers typically appear as large, deep burns or lesions, rather than serpiginous lesions. The injury is usually more localized and severe rather than serpentine.

questions.text: 7 week old male child with projectile non- Bilious vomiting. Which electrolyte imbalance can be seen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hypochloremic Hypokalemic alkalosis. The scenario described is classic for pyloric stenosis, a condition where there is hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, causing obstruction and leading to projectile non-bilious vomiting. The vomiting results in the loss of gastric contents, which are rich in hydrochloric acid (HCl). This leads to a hypochloremic alkalosis, as the body compensates by retaining bicarbonate to balance the loss of acid. Additionally, the loss of potassium through vomiting results in hypokalemia. Therefore, hypochloremic hypokalemic alkalosis is the typical electrolyte imbalance seen in this condition. Incorrect Responses: B. Hyperchloremic Hyperkalemic alkalosis: This option is incorrect because pyloric stenosis leads to a loss of chloride, not an increase. Additionally, hyperkalemia is not typically seen in this condition, as the vomiting causes potassium loss, not retention. C. Hyperchloremic Hypokalemic alkalosis: This is incorrect because the vomiting in pyloric stenosis leads to a loss of chloride, not an increase. Therefore, hyperchloremic is not consistent with the typical presentation. D. Hypochloremic Hyperkalemic alkalosis: This is incorrect because, in pyloric stenosis, vomiting leads to hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia. The loss of potassium due to vomiting is a key feature of this condition, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Which is fluid of choice for CHPS?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 5% Dextrose + 0.45% NACL + 20 mg of KCL. The treatment for Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis (CHPS) involves rehydration and correcting electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypochloremic, hypokalemic alkalosis due to vomiting. The fluid of choice typically contains 5% dextrose, which provides glucose for energy, and 0.45% sodium chloride (NACL) to help restore sodium levels. Additionally, potassium chloride (KCL) is added (usually around 20 mEq) to correct the hypokalemia that often accompanies vomiting. The concentration of sodium chloride is reduced to 0.45% to avoid exacerbating the alkalosis and to restore proper fluid balance without overloading the body with excess sodium. Incorrect Responses: A. 5% Dextrose + 0.9% NACL + 20 mg of KCL: This option contains 0.9% NACL, which is a normal saline concentration. Although it is sometimes used in other clinical scenarios, in CHPS, this concentration may exacerbate the hypochloremic alkalosis due to its higher chloride content. The ideal fluid contains a lower sodium chloride concentration (0.45%) to prevent further imbalance. C. 5% Dextrose + 0.9% NACL + 5 mg of KCL: The potassium content (5 mg) in this option is insufficient to correct the significant hypokalemia commonly seen in CHPS. Typically, 20 mEq of potassium chloride is required for appropriate repletion of potassium in the body, making this option inadequate for managing electrolyte imbalances. D. 10% Dextrose + 0.9% NACL + 20 mg of KCL: 10% dextrose is too concentrated and could lead to hyperglycemia, especially in an infant. The goal is to provide a controlled, moderate amount of glucose, which is achieved with 5% dextrose. This higher concentration of dextrose would not be suitable for this rehydration protocol.

questions.text: The abdominal mass in pyloric stenosis in a new born child can be best palpated at?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In the epigastric area. In pyloric stenosis, the abdominal mass associated with the hypertrophied pyloric muscle is best palpated in the epigastric area. This is typically felt as an olive-shaped mass. It is most prominent during or shortly after feeding when the stomach is distended and the pyloric muscle is engaged. The epigastric region is the area located just below the sternum and above the umbilicus, where the pylorus is situated. Incorrect Responses: A. During feeding: While the mass may become more noticeable during or after feeding, it is not typically palpated only during feeding. The mass itself is best palpated in the epigastric region, regardless of the timing of feeding. However, feeding does increase the likelihood of feeling the mass due to the gastric distension. B. In the umbilical area: The umbilical area is not the correct location for palpating the mass associated with pyloric stenosis. The hypertrophied pylorus is located higher up, in the epigastric region, and not near the umbilicus. D. In the right hypochondriac quadrant: The right hypochondriac quadrant is located under the ribs on the right side of the abdomen and is not the area where the pyloric mass is found. The mass in pyloric stenosis is more accurately located in the epigastric area, which is central and slightly above the umbilicus.

questions.text: Most common site of gastric ulcer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Lesser curvature at incisura angularis. The most common site for gastric ulcers is the lesser curvature at the incisura angularis, located along the inner curve of the stomach. This area is particularly vulnerable because it is near the junction between the body and antrum of the stomach, where the acid secretion is most concentrated. The incisura angularis is a natural indentation in the stomach’s lesser curvature, making it an area where ulcers are more likely to form, especially in the presence of factors like Helicobacter pylori infection or prolonged use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Incorrect Responses: B. Greater curvature: Ulcers on the greater curvature of the stomach are less common compared to the lesser curvature. The greater curvature is located on the outer curve of the stomach, where the acid exposure is not as intense as along the lesser curvature, making it a less likely site for ulcer formation. C. Pyloric antrum: Although ulcers can occur in the pyloric antrum, which is the lower part of the stomach near the pyloric sphincter, it is not the most common site. The pyloric antrum is more commonly associated with duodenal ulcers rather than gastric ulcers. The acid in this region is less concentrated compared to the lesser curvature. D. Fundus: Gastric ulcers in the fundus (the upper part of the stomach) are relatively rare. The fundus typically has lower acid secretion compared to the rest of the stomach, making it less susceptible to ulcer formation. Most gastric ulcers are found in areas where acid secretion is highest, such as the lesser curvature.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of endoscopic treatment in bleeding peptic ulcer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Visible vessel at base. The presence of a visible vessel at the base of a peptic ulcer is a strong indication for endoscopic treatment. This suggests active bleeding or a high risk of rebleeding. Endoscopic interventions, such as thermal coagulation, injection therapy, or mechanical hemostasis, are used to treat these ulcers by either cauterizing the vessel or applying other methods to stop the bleeding. If a visible vessel is seen, it requires immediate attention to prevent ongoing or recurrent bleeding. Incorrect Responses: A. Clot at base: A clot at the base of the ulcer indicates that bleeding has occurred but may not represent an active or ongoing bleeding source. Clots themselves are not an indication for immediate endoscopic intervention unless there is evidence of active bleeding or a high risk of rebleeding. The presence of a clot could be managed with conservative measures unless other factors suggest the need for endoscopy. B. Clots in stomach: Clots in the stomach suggest previous bleeding, but like the clot at the base, they do not necessarily indicate ongoing or high-risk bleeding. The management would depend on whether the source of the bleeding can be identified or if there is a recurrent or active bleeding point, which would require endoscopy for treatment. D. Non bleeding ulcer bed: A non-bleeding ulcer bed is not an indication for endoscopic treatment. If the ulcer is not actively bleeding, the focus would be on medical management and monitoring. Endoscopic treatment is typically reserved for actively bleeding ulcers or those at high risk of rebleeding, not for non-bleeding ulcer beds.

questions.text: An adult male presented with symptoms of duodenal ulcer. Maximum chances of recurrence with minimal morbidity would be seen after?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Gastrojejunostomy. A gastrojejunostomy is a surgical procedure that connects the stomach directly to the jejunum, bypassing the duodenum. This is often done in patients with duodenal ulcers, especially in those with complications like gastric outlet obstruction or when other treatments are not effective. While gastrojejunostomy carries a risk of recurrence, it generally results in minimal morbidity compared to other more invasive surgeries, such as gastrectomy. The procedure reduces the acid exposure to the duodenum, thereby decreasing the chances of ulcer recurrence in the duodenum, even though ulcers may recur elsewhere. The functional benefits of this procedure, such as restoring normal gastric emptying, help minimize complications in the long term. Incorrect Responses: A. Truncal vagotomy: Truncal vagotomy involves cutting the vagus nerve, which decreases acid secretion in the stomach. While it may reduce ulcer recurrence, it carries a higher risk of complications, including gastroparesis, diarrhea, and impaired gastric emptying, which can result in significant morbidity. This procedure has a higher risk of complications than gastrojejunostomy. B. Highly selective vagotomy: A highly selective vagotomy involves cutting only the vagal fibers that supply the acid-secreting part of the stomach (the fundus and body). While this technique reduces the chances of ulcer recurrence, it does not offer the same benefit in terms of bypassing the duodenum and may still have a chance of recurrence, especially if other factors like Helicobacter pylori infection are present. It is effective but might not be as favorable in minimizing recurrence with minimal morbidity compared to gastrojejunostomy. C. Gastrectomy: Gastrectomy (partial or total removal of the stomach) is a more invasive procedure and generally results in more morbidity compared to gastrojejunostomy. While it can effectively eliminate the source of ulcer formation, it has a higher risk of nutritional deficiencies, dumping syndrome, and weight loss, making it a less favorable option for minimizing long-term morbidity.

questions.text: In a patient with Carcinoma stomach with GOO, invading in Head of pancreas with metastasis in Right lobe of Liver. Next best treatment is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Palliative Gastrojejunostomy with chemotherapy. In a patient with carcinoma of the stomach that has resulted in gastric outlet obstruction (GOO), invasion of the head of the pancreas, and metastasis to the liver, the disease is considered advanced and metastatic. Surgical resection is not feasible due to the spread of the cancer, particularly to the liver and pancreas. In such cases, the goal is to provide palliative care to improve the patient’s quality of life and relieve symptoms such as obstruction. Palliative gastrojejunostomy can help by bypassing the obstruction and restoring gastric outlet function, which helps alleviate nausea, vomiting, and malnutrition. Chemotherapy may be used in conjunction to help manage the cancer and slow its progression. Incorrect Responses: B. Whipple’s operation with chemotherapy: The Whipple procedure (pancreaticoduodenectomy) is typically performed for tumors localized to the head of the pancreas. However, in this case, the cancer has already invaded the head of the pancreas, and there is metastasis to the liver, making the Whipple procedure inappropriate. It is not suitable for metastatic or locally advanced disease because it will not address the widespread cancer or offer a significant survival benefit. C. Radical gastrectomy + right hepatectomy: Radical gastrectomy and right hepatectomy involve extensive surgery to remove the stomach and a portion of the liver. However, because the cancer has already spread to the liver (with metastasis), this surgery would not be curative. It would also significantly increase morbidity and may not provide meaningful survival benefit in a patient with advanced metastatic disease. D. Follow up: Simply doing follow-up without any therapeutic intervention would not be appropriate in this case. Given the gastric outlet obstruction, the pancreatic invasion, and liver metastasis, the patient requires treatment to alleviate symptoms and manage the advanced cancer, rather than just observation.

questions.text: In a patient complaining dyspepsia, upper GI endoscopy and biopsy revealed low grade MALToma. What is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Antibiotics. In a patient with low-grade MALT lymphoma (Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue lymphoma), especially when associated with Helicobacter pylori infection, the first-line treatment is antibiotics aimed at eradicating the H. pylori bacteria. In fact, H. pylori infection is known to play a significant role in the development of MALT lymphoma, and antibiotic therapy to eradicate the infection can lead to remission of the lymphoma in many cases. This approach is highly effective in patients with localized, low-grade MALT lymphoma, as successful eradication of H. pylori can lead to regression of the lymphoma without the need for more aggressive treatments like chemotherapy or surgery. Incorrect Responses: B. Surgery: Surgery is not the primary treatment for low-grade MALT lymphoma unless there is a specific complication that requires surgical intervention (e.g., obstruction or perforation). Since low-grade MALT lymphoma is typically indolent and responds well to antibiotic therapy, surgery is generally not indicated. C. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy is typically reserved for more aggressive forms of lymphoma or when the disease does not respond to first-line treatment like antibiotics. Since low-grade MALT lymphoma can often be treated effectively with antibiotics alone (especially when associated with H. pylori), chemotherapy is not typically the first treatment option. D. Surgery with Chemotherapy: As stated above, surgery and chemotherapy are not standard treatments for low-grade MALT lymphoma, particularly when it is associated with H. pylori infection. Eradication of H. pylori with antibiotics is usually sufficient for treatment, and surgery or chemotherapy would be reserved for more advanced or aggressive cases.

questions.text: A patient presented to casualty with complaints of pain abdomen since 4 days, fever and obstruction. X-ray abdomen erect was done as depicted below .What is the possible pathology.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hollow viscus perforation. In a patient presenting with abdominal pain, fever, and features of intestinal obstruction, along with an erect abdominal X-ray showing free air under the diaphragm (pneumoperitoneum), the most likely diagnosis is hollow viscus perforation. The presence of free gas under the diaphragm on imaging is a classic radiologic sign indicating that air has escaped from a perforated gastrointestinal structure (such as the stomach, small intestine, or colon) into the peritoneal cavity. This is a surgical emergency, as it can rapidly lead to peritonitis and sepsis, requiring prompt surgical intervention. Incorrect Responses: B. Liver abscess: A liver abscess typically presents with right upper quadrant pain, fever, and tender hepatomegaly, but it does not produce free air under the diaphragm. Imaging (such as ultrasound or CT) would show a hypoechoic or cystic lesion in the liver rather than pneumoperitoneum. C. Subphrenic abscess: This condition may present with fever and abdominal pain, and may even mimic intraperitoneal pathology, but air under the diaphragm is not a common radiographic finding unless the abscess contains gas-forming organisms and ruptures, which is rare. It is also more commonly associated with postoperative complications. D. Empyema thorax: Empyema is an infection in the pleural space (around the lungs), presenting with chest pain, fever, dyspnea, and possibly a pleural effusion on chest imaging. It does not cause pneumoperitoneum or free air under the diaphragm on abdominal X-ray, and is a thoracic, not abdominal, condition.

questions.text: A patient came to emergency room with severe abdominal pain. Pulse 112 beats/ min and SBP is 80 mmHg. Chest X-ray shown below. What will be the next step of management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Resuscitation then exploratory laparotomy. In a patient presenting with severe abdominal pain, tachycardia (pulse 112/min), and hypotension (SBP 80 mmHg), along with radiologic evidence (such as pneumoperitoneum on chest X-ray) suggestive of hollow viscus perforation, the patient is in hypovolemic shock likely due to peritonitis and sepsis. The priority in management is initial resuscitation—which includes intravenous fluid administration, correction of electrolyte imbalance, oxygen support, and possibly broad-spectrum antibiotics. Once the patient is hemodynamically stabilized to the extent possible, they should undergo emergency exploratory laparotomy to identify and repair the perforation. Resuscitation is essential before surgery to reduce perioperative morbidity and mortality in a patient who is in shock. Incorrect Responses: A. Exploratory Laparotomy: While surgery is necessary, immediate laparotomy without resuscitation in a patient with signs of shock can be dangerous. Operating on an unstable patient increases the risk of anesthesia-related complications and poor surgical outcomes. Resuscitation must precede definitive surgical intervention. C. CT scan: In a hemodynamically unstable patient, a CT scan is not appropriate as it delays definitive management and may be unsafe. Imaging studies beyond plain films are only appropriate in stable patients. In this case, the diagnosis is already apparent (perforation with pneumoperitoneum), and the priority is treatment. D. Laparoscopy: Although laparoscopy can be used in stable patients for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes, in unstable patients with generalized peritonitis, open exploratory laparotomy is the gold standard. Laparoscopy takes longer, may not offer adequate exposure, and is typically contraindicated in severely unstable patients.

choices.text: Plain X ray shows double bubble sign.
Commonest presenting symptom is bilious vomiting few hours after birth.

questions.text: False statement regarding duodenal atresia is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Obstetrical Ultrasound shows oligohydramnios (In 50%). This statement is false because duodenal atresia is typically associated with polyhydramnios, not oligohydramnios. Polyhydramnios occurs in approximately 30–50% of cases due to the fetus's inability to swallow and absorb amniotic fluid because of the duodenal blockage. The fluid accumulates as it cannot pass beyond the obstruction, leading to increased amniotic fluid volume on antenatal ultrasound. Therefore, option C is incorrect, making it the false statement in the question. Incorrect Options (True Statements): A. Plain X-ray shows double bubble sign: This is true and a classic radiographic finding in duodenal atresia. The "double bubble" sign refers to air trapped in the stomach and the proximal duodenum, with no gas seen distally, which is diagnostic of complete obstruction such as in duodenal atresia. B. Commonest presenting symptom is bilious vomiting few hours after birth: This is also true. Most neonates with duodenal atresia present with bilious vomiting shortly after birth, as the obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater. In some rare cases, if the atresia is proximal to the ampulla, vomiting may be non-bilious. D. Treatment of choice is duodeno-duodenostomy: This is correct. The definitive treatment for duodenal atresia is surgical repair, most commonly through a duodeno-duodenostomy, which involves connecting the proximal and distal segments of the duodenum to bypass the atretic segment and restore continuity of the intestinal tract.

questions.text: Most common type of gallstone is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Mixed stones. Mixed gallstones are the most common type of gallstones, accounting for the majority of cases seen clinically. These stones are composed primarily of cholesterol, but they also contain varying amounts of calcium salts, bile pigments, and phospholipids, which give them a variable appearance and consistency. Mixed stones typically form in conditions where cholesterol is supersaturated in bile, and they may also be associated with impaired gallbladder motility and bile stasis. They are often radiolucent, meaning they do not show up on plain X-rays, although some may have enough calcium to be partially radio-opaque. These stones are frequently found in patients with risk factors such as obesity, high-fat diets, and metabolic syndrome. Incorrect Options: B. Pure cholesterol stones: While cholesterol stones are a major component of gallstones, pure cholesterol stones are less common than mixed stones. Pure cholesterol stones are typically pale yellow and form when bile becomes overly saturated with cholesterol and there is a deficiency in bile acids and phospholipids. They are more commonly seen in patients on parenteral nutrition or rapid weight loss but are not the most prevalent type overall. C. Pigment stones: Pigment stones are composed primarily of calcium bilirubinate and are black or brown. They are more commonly seen in conditions such as hemolytic anemia, cirrhosis, or biliary tract infections. While pigment stones are relatively common in certain populations, they are less prevalent overall compared to mixed stones. D. Calcium bilirubinate stones: These are a subtype of pigment stones, specifically brown pigment stones, and are often associated with biliary infections and parasitic infestations in the biliary system. Though they are significant in some geographic regions and clinical settings, they are not the most common type of gallstone overall.

questions.text: Type of cholesterol present in gall stones is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Crystalline cholesterol monohydrate The type of cholesterol present in gallstones is crystalline cholesterol monohydrate. This form is the most thermodynamically stable and commonly found in cholesterol-based gallstones. When bile becomes supersaturated with cholesterol—usually due to an imbalance in bile salts, phospholipids, and cholesterol—it precipitates out in the form of cholesterol monohydrate crystals. These crystals are the building blocks of cholesterol gallstones. Over time, with mucin and other nucleating factors, these crystals aggregate and grow to form macroscopic stones. Their crystalline structure gives the stones their solid, often radiolucent appearance and helps distinguish them from other forms of precipitate. (A) Amorphous cholesterol monohydrate – Incorrect: The cholesterol found in gallstones is not in an amorphous form. Amorphous refers to a non-crystalline, disordered structure, which is not the stable form typically found in gallstones. Gallstones require a structured, ordered lattice to form solid stones, hence the crystalline form predominates. (B) Amorphous cholesterol dihydrate – Incorrect: This option is incorrect for two reasons: it is amorphous and it is a dihydrate form. Neither characteristic is typical of the cholesterol found in gallstones. Cholesterol in an amorphous or hydrated dihydrate state is not stable in bile and would not form durable gallstones. (C) Crystalline cholesterol dihydrate – Incorrect: While this option includes the correct "crystalline" structure, the dihydrate form of cholesterol is not the one typically found in gallstones. The monohydrate form is the stable, naturally occurring variant under physiological conditions in bile and is the main constituent of cholesterol stones.

questions.text: A 40 years old patient came in emergency department with abdominal colic and features of obstructive jaundice. Her counts and liver enzymes were elevated. A USG was done and gallbladder was scleroatrophic and CBD was impacted with stones along with IHBR dilation. Which is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ERCP-MRCP The next appropriate step in the management of this patient is ERCP-MRCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography – Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography). The patient presents with classic signs of obstructive jaundice, including abdominal colic, elevated liver enzymes, and a dilated common bile duct (CBD) impacted with stones, as confirmed by ultrasonography. In such a scenario, ERCP serves both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes—it can confirm the presence of stones in the CBD and allows for stone extraction and biliary decompression. MRCP, a non-invasive imaging tool, is often used as a preliminary or complementary step to visualize the biliary tree before intervention. Therefore, ERCP-MRCP is the most logical next step to both establish a definitive diagnosis and proceed with immediate relief of obstruction. (A) Cholecystectomy – Incorrect: Although cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for gallbladder pathology, it is not the first step in a patient with an acutely obstructed CBD and scleroatrophic gallbladder. Attempting cholecystectomy in the presence of active obstruction and inflammation, especially with a shrunken gallbladder, increases the risk of complications. The obstruction must be relieved first with ERCP. (B) CT Scan – Incorrect: A CT scan is less sensitive than MRCP for visualizing biliary stones and the biliary tree. While it can be useful in identifying complications like perforation or malignancy, it is not the preferred imaging modality for confirming choledocholithiasis or guiding immediate intervention. The diagnosis has already been established on USG; further imaging should aim at therapeutic planning, which ERCP can address. (D) Wait & watch – Incorrect: This approach is inappropriate and potentially dangerous in a patient with signs of obstructive jaundice and laboratory abnormalities indicating biliary obstruction and possible cholangitis. Delaying treatment can lead to worsening infection, sepsis, or liver damage. Immediate intervention is warranted.

questions.text: Patient presented with pain in right upper abdomen. MRCP image given below. Next step in the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) ERCP The most appropriate next step in management is ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography). The patient presents with right upper quadrant pain and has undergone an MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography), which likely shows choledocholithiasis (common bile duct stones) or biliary obstruction. ERCP is indicated in this scenario because it allows both confirmation of the diagnosis and, more importantly, therapeutic intervention—specifically stone extraction, sphincterotomy, and biliary drainage. When MRCP has already identified an obstructive lesion, ERCP becomes the logical next step to relieve the obstruction and prevent complications like cholangitis or pancreatitis. (A) Cholecystectomy – Incorrect: While cholecystectomy is the definitive treatment for gallbladder stones, it is not the immediate next step in a patient with suspected CBD stones. Obstruction needs to be relieved first, typically with ERCP, before performing surgery. Proceeding directly to cholecystectomy without addressing ductal stones increases surgical risk and can lead to incomplete treatment. (C) CECT – Incorrect: Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) is not the most effective modality for evaluating the biliary tree or diagnosing choledocholithiasis. Since MRCP already provides excellent visualization of the bile ducts and likely revealed the pathology, CECT would be redundant and less useful in this context. (D) PTC – Incorrect: Percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography (PTC) is an invasive procedure used typically when ERCP is unsuccessful or not feasible (e.g., altered surgical anatomy). It is not the first-line intervention when ERCP is available and technically possible. Therefore, it is not appropriate as the next step in this case.

questions.text: 60 year old female with multiple episodes of bilious vomiting and abdominal distention with increased bowel sounds. (X ray abdomen is s/o air fluid levels, Pneumobilia and Features of small bowel obstruction)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gallstone ileus The most likely diagnosis is gallstone ileus. This condition occurs when a large gallstone passes into the small intestine through a biliary-enteric fistula (usually a cholecysto-duodenal fistula), causing small bowel obstruction. The classic radiological findings supporting gallstone ileus include air-fluid levels, pneumobilia (air in the biliary system), and features of small bowel obstruction, which are present in the X-ray. The episodes of bilious vomiting and abdominal distension further support this diagnosis, as these are typical symptoms of bowel obstruction caused by a large gallstone. Gallstone ileus is more common in older females and can present with recurrent episodes, as described in this case. (B) Ischemic enterocolitis – Incorrect: Ischemic enterocolitis usually presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, or rectal bleeding, especially in patients with risk factors like cardiovascular disease or hypotension. It leads to reduced blood flow to the bowel, causing mucosal damage. However, the presence of pneumobilia and air-fluid levels on X-ray are not typical of ischemic enterocolitis. Additionally, ischemic enterocolitis doesn't typically cause mechanical obstruction like in gallstone ileus. (C) GI TB – Incorrect: Gastrointestinal tuberculosis (GI TB) can present with symptoms like abdominal pain, weight loss, and malnutrition, often affecting the ileocecal region. However, GI TB is less likely to cause pneumobilia and air-fluid levels associated with small bowel obstruction. The X-ray findings do not fit well with GI TB, as this condition usually presents with bowel wall thickening, strictures, or masses rather than a mechanical obstruction caused by a gallstone. (D) Adynamic obstruction – Incorrect: Adynamic (or paralytic) obstruction occurs due to intestinal motility issues and results in diffuse bowel distention and absence of bowel sounds (hypoactive or absent), rather than increased bowel sounds, as noted in the patient. The key radiological finding in adynamic obstruction is usually generalized distension without focal air-fluid levels or pneumobilia. The presence of air-fluid levels and pneumobilia is not typical of adynamic obstruction, making this diagnosis unlikely.

choices.text: Usual site of obstruction is Distal ileum.

questions.text: False statement about Gall stone ileus is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rigler’s triad is seen in 10-15% The false statement is that Rigler’s triad is seen in 10-15% of cases. In reality, Rigler’s triad—which consists of pneumobilia, small bowel obstruction, and an ectopic gallstone—is seen in only 25-40% of gallstone ileus cases, not just 10-15%. It is a classic radiological finding that helps diagnose gallstone ileus but is not as universally present in all cases. The relatively low occurrence of Rigler’s triad indicates that not all patients with gallstone ileus will have this triad visible on imaging. (A) Usual site of obstruction is distal ileum – Correct: The most common site of obstruction in gallstone ileus is the distal ileum. This occurs because the gallstone, after passing through a biliary-enteric fistula, travels down the small intestine until it gets lodged in the ileum due to its narrow lumen. The distal ileum is the site where the stone typically causes obstruction, resulting in small bowel obstruction symptoms such as vomiting, abdominal distension, and pain. (C) Gallstone causes intermittent obstruction – Correct: Gallstone ileus can cause intermittent obstruction because the stone may temporarily move within the bowel, resulting in episodes of obstruction. The stone may shift, and the obstruction may resolve if the stone moves further down the intestinal tract, leading to periods of relief, only for the obstruction to recur as the stone becomes lodged again. (D) Pneumobilia is an ubiquitous sign – Correct: Pneumobilia (air in the biliary tree) is a very common finding in gallstone ileus because of the biliary-enteric fistula that allows air from the intestines to enter the biliary system. This sign is often seen in the majority of cases of gallstone ileus and is one of the key features that helps distinguish it from other causes of small bowel obstruction.

questions.text: Mascagni node is encountered in which surgery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Laparoscopic Cholecystectomy The Mascagni node is encountered during laparoscopic cholecystectomy. It refers to the lymph node located at the junction of the cystic duct and common bile duct. This node, also known as the node of Luschka, is typically encountered during the dissection of the cystic duct in laparoscopic cholecystectomy. While not always visible, this node is significant because it may need to be carefully identified and preserved or removed during surgery, especially if it becomes inflamed or enlarged. (A) Laparoscopic Splenectomy – Incorrect: Mascagni's node is not associated with laparoscopic splenectomy. This surgery involves the removal of the spleen, typically for conditions like trauma, splenomegaly, or hematological disorders. The dissection in splenectomy focuses on the splenic artery and vein, and the lymph nodes involved are usually related to the spleen, not the cystic duct or bile ducts. (B) Laparoscopic Appendicectomy – Incorrect: In laparoscopic appendicectomy, the procedure involves the removal of the appendix, typically through an approach that involves identifying and securing the mesoappendix. Mascagni's node is unrelated to appendicitis or appendectomy, as the lymphatic structures encountered in this surgery are those surrounding the appendix and mesoappendix. (C) Laparoscopic Adrenalectomy – Incorrect: Mascagni's node is not encountered in laparoscopic adrenalectomy either. This surgery involves the removal of one or both adrenal glands, typically for tumors or hyperfunction. The dissection here focuses on the adrenal glands and surrounding vasculature, not the bile duct or cystic duct, where the Mascagni node is found.

questions.text: In laparoscopic surgery what should be good manipulation angle for good ergonomics?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 60 degrees The optimal manipulation angle for good ergonomics in laparoscopic surgery is 60 degrees. This angle allows the surgeon to maintain a comfortable and stable posture while performing intricate tasks. The 60-degree angle helps avoid excessive strain on the arms, wrists, and shoulders, allowing for smoother and more precise movements during the procedure. By positioning the instruments at this angle, the surgeon can achieve better control and precision, thus improving overall performance and reducing fatigue during long procedures. (A) 15 degrees – Incorrect: A 15-degree angle is too shallow for effective laparoscopic manipulation. At such a small angle, the surgeon would have to extend their arms excessively, leading to potential fatigue and discomfort. This angle does not support optimal ergonomics or precision during surgery, as it places undue stress on the wrist and arm joints. (B) 30 degrees – Incorrect: While a 30-degree angle is slightly better than 15 degrees, it still does not provide the optimal balance between ergonomics and precision. At 30 degrees, the surgeon might still experience some discomfort and strain, especially during prolonged procedures. This angle is not as favorable as 60 degrees, which allows for better control and less fatigue. (D) 90 degrees – Incorrect: A 90-degree angle would result in a very unnatural wrist and arm position for the surgeon. This angle is too acute for laparoscopic surgery, requiring the surgeon to manipulate instruments in a way that would increase muscle strain and reduce precision. Such an angle would likely lead to poor ergonomics, making it difficult to perform the surgery with accuracy and comfort.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation can not be done after Mini-gastric bypass?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) ERCP ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is generally not performed after a mini-gastric bypass. In this type of surgery, the anatomy of the stomach and duodenum is altered significantly. The mini-gastric bypass involves the creation of a small gastric pouch that is connected to the jejunum, bypassing the normal route through the duodenum and the proximal small intestine. Due to this alteration in gastrointestinal anatomy, the standard ERCP approach, which typically requires a direct route to the duodenum for cannulating the ampulla of Vater, is not feasible after this surgery. Specialized techniques or adaptations are needed, and even then, ERCP is rarely performed. (B) MRCP – Incorrect: MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) is a non-invasive imaging technique that uses MRI to visualize the biliary and pancreatic ducts. It is unaffected by the surgical alterations made during a mini-gastric bypass, as it does not require any direct access to the gastrointestinal tract. MRCP can be safely performed after mini-gastric bypass to assess the biliary tree for conditions like gallstones, biliary strictures, or ductal dilatation. (C) PTBD – Incorrect: PTBD (Percutaneous Transhepatic Biliary Drainage) is an interventional procedure used to access and drain the biliary tree through the liver. This procedure is performed percutaneously through the skin and liver and is not dependent on the patient’s digestive tract anatomy. Therefore, PTBD can still be performed in patients who have undergone a mini-gastric bypass if biliary obstruction or other biliary issues are present. (D) EUS – Incorrect: EUS (Endoscopic Ultrasound) is a diagnostic procedure that uses an endoscope with an ultrasound probe to visualize the gastrointestinal tract and surrounding structures. EUS can be performed after mini-gastric bypass, as the procedure involves accessing the stomach and duodenum through the esophagus. While the surgical anatomy is altered, EUS can still be effectively used for evaluating the biliary system, pancreas, and other structures even in bypass patients.

questions.text: 2 years Post cholecystectomy patients comes with CBD stone. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Primary CBD stone In a patient who presents with CBD stones (common bile duct stones) two years after cholecystectomy, the most likely diagnosis is primary CBD stone. Primary CBD stones form in the common bile duct itself, often due to biliary stasis, infection, or other factors that disrupt normal bile flow. After cholecystectomy, bile flow is altered, and stasis can lead to the formation of new stones in the common bile duct, especially if there is any residual biliary dysfunction or strictures in the duct. Therefore, these stones are not related to the gallbladder and are classified as primary CBD stones. (B) Secondary CBD stone – Incorrect: Secondary CBD stones are those that migrate from the gallbladder into the common bile duct, typically caused by the presence of gallstones in the gallbladder. These stones are usually formed before cholecystectomy and pass into the CBD after the gallbladder is removed. In this case, since the patient is already two years post-cholecystectomy, it is less likely that the stones are secondary, especially if no stones were left behind at the time of surgery. (C) Retained stone – Incorrect: A retained stone refers to a stone that was not removed during the original cholecystectomy or CBD exploration. However, if a stone had been retained after surgery, it would typically present with symptoms soon after the procedure. A two-year delay in the presentation of symptoms makes a retained stone less likely, as it would usually cause problems sooner if it had been missed. (D) Missed stone – Incorrect: A missed stone would imply that a stone was present during the original surgery but was overlooked or not detected. This could occur if the surgeon did not adequately explore the CBD during cholecystectomy. However, two years after the procedure, it would be unusual for a missed stone to remain asymptomatic for such a long period. Additionally, the patient’s presentation suggests the stones formed post-surgery, making the "missed stone" diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: Gall bladder cancer at Fundus, infiltrating up to serosa, not going beyond serosa and not involving liver.stage is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) According to the TNM staging system for gallbladder cancer, a T2 tumor is defined by its invasion of the perimuscular connective tissue without penetrating the serosa. The provided description—infiltrating up to the serosa but not going beyond it, and not invading the liver—is a perfect match for the criteria of a T2 tumor. A T1b tumor would only invade the muscular layer, while T3 and T4 tumors would involve deeper invasion through the serosa or into adjacent organs like the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of selective shunt?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sarfeh shunt The Sarfeh shunt is an example of a selective shunt. This type of shunt is designed to bypass only the portal hypertension while preserving the liver's blood flow. The Sarfeh shunt creates a selective diversion of blood from the portal circulation to the systemic circulation without completely bypassing the liver, thus allowing for continued liver perfusion. This selective nature of the shunt makes it ideal for patients with portal hypertension who still require adequate liver function. (B) Mesocaval shunt – Incorrect: The mesocaval shunt is a non-selective shunt that involves the creation of a direct connection between the mesenteric vein and the inferior vena cava. This procedure bypasses the entire portal circulation, which can lead to a loss of blood flow to the liver. As a result, this is not a selective shunt, as it does not preserve liver perfusion. (C) Portocaval shunt – Incorrect: The portocaval shunt is another non-selective shunt that connects the portal vein to the inferior vena cava. This shunt also bypasses the portal circulation entirely, which results in a decreased blood supply to the liver. Like the mesocaval shunt, it is not selective because it does not allow for the preservation of liver blood flow. (D) Rex shunt – Incorrect: The Rex shunt is a type of portosystemic shunt but is considered non-selective. It connects the portal vein to the inferior vena cava via a channel created between the left portal vein and the inferior vena cava. The Rex shunt is used in patients with conditions like portal hypertension, but, like other non-selective shunts, it does not preserve liver blood flow and is therefore not considered a selective shunt.

questions.text: Most common site for intra abdominal abscess in relation to liver?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right subhepatic space The right subhepatic space is the most common site for an intra-abdominal abscess in relation to the liver. This is due to its proximity to the right lobe of the liver and the gallbladder, both of which are common sources of infection, especially following conditions like cholecystitis or liver abscesses. The right subhepatic space is located between the liver and the duodenum, making it a frequent site for abscess formation, particularly in cases of biliary tract infections, trauma, or post-surgical complications. (A) Right Subphrenic space – Incorrect: The right subphrenic space is located beneath the diaphragm on the right side and is another potential site for intra-abdominal abscesses, but it is less common than the right subhepatic space. Infections here are often related to perforation of abdominal organs, like the stomach or bowel, or post-surgical procedures. While an abscess can form in this space, it is not the most common site in relation to the liver. (B) Left Subphrenic abscess – Incorrect: The left subphrenic space is located beneath the diaphragm on the left side and can also be a site for intra-abdominal abscesses, especially following splenic or gastric perforations. However, it is less commonly associated with liver-related abscesses compared to the right subhepatic space. (D) Left subhepatic space – Incorrect: The left subhepatic space is located beneath the left lobe of the liver and is less commonly involved in abscess formation compared to the right subhepatic space. This is due to the anatomy and blood supply of the liver, which makes the right side more prone to infections, especially those originating from the biliary system. While abscesses can occur here, it is not the most common site for liver-related abscesses.

choices.text: Large sip of water of fizzy drink to push the food bolus down

questions.text: Adult male while eating in a restaurant develops sudden choking.What should be done next?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Heimlich maneuver The Heimlich maneuver is the appropriate and most effective first aid response for someone who is choking due to a food bolus or other obstruction in the airway. This technique involves applying abdominal thrusts to create an artificial cough that forces the object out of the airway. The Heimlich maneuver is specifically designed to expel foreign objects blocking the airway, which can be life-saving in situations where the person cannot breathe or speak. This maneuver is universally recommended for adults who are choking. (B) Chest thumping – Incorrect: Chest thumping is not an effective method for treating choking in adults. It involves striking the chest, which does not generate the necessary force to expel a food bolus or obstruction from the airway. Unlike abdominal thrusts, chest thumping does not create the necessary pressure or airflow to clear the airway. (C) Blind finger extraction – Incorrect: While blind finger extraction might be performed in some cases, it is generally not recommended in a conscious adult who is choking. Attempting to reach into the throat without being able to see the obstruction could lead to further injury, push the object deeper, or make the airway completely blocked. This method should only be attempted by trained medical personnel and in situations where the Heimlich maneuver is not effective or possible. (D) Large sip of water or fizzy drink to push the food bolus down – Incorrect: Drinking water or a fizzy drink is not recommended in a choking emergency. When a person is choking, they are unable to swallow properly, and trying to drink may worsen the blockage by pushing the food or object further down the airway. Water is not effective at dislodging an object that is stuck in the throat. Immediate action like the Heimlich maneuver is needed to expel the object quickly.

questions.text: Gas-less abdomen is seen in?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute pancreatitis In acute pancreatitis, a gas-less abdomen may be seen due to the lack of bowel gas or gas distension. This happens because the inflammation of the pancreas can lead to disruption of normal gastrointestinal motility and bowel paralysis, which reduces bowel gas movement and results in a relatively gas-free appearance on radiographic imaging. Additionally, in severe cases, peritoneal fluid collections or fluid sequestration in the abdomen may contribute to the gas-less appearance. (A) Ulcerative colitis – Incorrect: Ulcerative colitis is characterized by inflammation and ulceration of the colon, which typically leads to diarrhea and can result in distension or gas accumulation in the colon, not a gas-less abdomen. While there may be some complications like perforation or toxic megacolon that could affect the appearance of the abdomen, gas accumulation is more likely than a gas-less abdomen in these cases. (C) Intussusception – Incorrect: Intussusception, a condition where one part of the intestine telescopes into a neighboring part, typically presents with bowel obstruction. On imaging, this usually leads to the accumulation of gas in the intestines, as the bowel is unable to pass contents beyond the point of obstruction. Therefore, a gas-less abdomen is not typical in intussusception. (D) Necrotizing enterocolitis – Incorrect: Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) is a severe gastrointestinal condition often seen in preterm infants, characterized by intestinal ischemia and necrosis. While there may be a reduction in bowel activity or perfusion, leading to gasless bowel segments in some advanced cases, it is more typically associated with gas-filled bowel loops and pneumatosis intestinalis (gas within the bowel wall) on imaging rather than a completely gas-less abdomen.

questions.text: A 40 female presented to surgery casualty with mild Pain abdomen, abdominal distention since 4 days.USG is s/o Peripancreatic fluid collection.whic of the following will be raised ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Serum lipase In this case, the patient presents with mild abdominal pain, abdominal distention, and peripancreatic fluid collection on ultrasound, which strongly suggests acute pancreatitis or its complications, such as a pancreatic pseudocyst. Serum lipase is an enzyme produced by the pancreas, and its levels rise significantly in response to pancreatic inflammation. Elevated lipase is a hallmark of acute pancreatitis and can remain elevated for several days after the initial onset of symptoms, making it the best indicator in this scenario. (B) GGT – Incorrect: Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT) is a liver enzyme typically elevated in conditions affecting the liver, biliary tract, or alcohol consumption. While it may be mildly elevated in some pancreatic diseases if there is concurrent bile duct involvement or obstruction, it is not the primary marker for diagnosing pancreatitis or peripancreatic fluid collections. GGT is more relevant for liver function issues rather than isolated pancreatic pathology. (C) Bilirubin – Incorrect: Bilirubin is a byproduct of hemoglobin breakdown and is typically elevated in conditions involving liver dysfunction or biliary obstruction, such as gallstones, hepatitis, or cholestasis. Although elevated bilirubin can occur in pancreatitis if there is obstruction of the common bile duct, it is not the most specific or sensitive marker in this case, especially when the primary concern is peripancreatic fluid collection rather than biliary tract involvement. (D) CEA – Incorrect: Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) is a tumor marker often elevated in various types of cancers, especially those of the gastrointestinal tract like colorectal cancer. It is not a useful marker for acute pancreatitis or peripancreatic fluid collection. CEA may be elevated in cases of pancreatic cancer, but it is not relevant in the context of acute pancreatitis or its early complications.

questions.text: Acute pancreatitis with worsening clinical features.CT scan showing infected necrosis, and peri-pancreatic fluid collection.This is best managed by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Percutaneous drainage In cases of acute pancreatitis with worsening clinical features, infected necrosis, and peripancreatic fluid collection, percutaneous drainage is the best management option. This procedure involves inserting a catheter through the skin to drain infected fluid or pus from the peripancreatic space. Percutaneous drainage is less invasive than surgical options and is effective in managing infected pancreatic necrosis, helping to control infection and stabilize the patient. It is often done under CT or ultrasound guidance to ensure proper placement of the drainage catheter. This approach is widely used in clinical practice for patients who do not require immediate surgery but still have significant infection or fluid collection. (A) Conservative Treatment – Incorrect: Conservative treatment involves supportive care such as hydration, pain management, and nutritional support, which is the initial management for most cases of acute pancreatitis. However, in cases with infected necrosis and peripancreatic fluid collection, conservative treatment alone is not sufficient. Infected necrosis requires drainage to prevent systemic sepsis and further complications. Conservative treatment would not adequately address the ongoing infection in this scenario. (B) Laparoscopic lavage of peritoneum – Incorrect: While laparoscopic lavage can be used in some cases for intra-abdominal infections, it is not the preferred option for managing infected pancreatic necrosis. Laparoscopic procedures are generally not effective in draining pancreatic necrosis because the infection is typically located in deeper pancreatic and peripancreatic spaces. Therefore, percutaneous drainage is preferred as it directly addresses the source of infection and fluid accumulation without the need for more invasive surgery. (C) Internal drainage – Incorrect: Internal drainage refers to techniques that involve creating a connection between the pancreas and another part of the gastrointestinal tract, such as a pancreaticojejunostomy, in the setting of chronic pancreatitis or pancreatic pseudocysts. However, this is not the appropriate approach for acute pancreatitis with infected necrosis, as it does not address the immediate need for fluid drainage and infection control. Internal drainage would be considered more for managing long-term complications of pancreatitis rather than acute infectious complications.

questions.text: A 8 year old child is brought with well defined mass in epigastrium. He met with an accident 6 weeks back when he fell accidentally and sustained injury in his upper abdomen. What is the most probable cause for this swelling?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pseudocyst of pancreas The most probable cause for the well-defined mass in the epigastrium in this 8-year-old child, who sustained an abdominal injury 6 weeks ago, is a pseudocyst of the pancreas. Pancreatic pseudocysts often form as a result of trauma to the pancreas, particularly in children. After the initial injury, the pancreas can develop a fluid collection surrounded by a fibrous wall, which can present as a well-defined abdominal mass. These pseudocysts can take several weeks to form, and the timing of the presentation (6 weeks post-injury) aligns with the development of a pseudocyst. The mass is typically located in the epigastrium due to the proximity of the pancreas to this area. (A) Gastric duplication cyst – Incorrect: A gastric duplication cyst is a rare congenital anomaly where a portion of the stomach is duplicated and forms a cystic structure. It can present as an abdominal mass, but it is usually present from birth or develops shortly after birth, not several weeks after an abdominal injury. Furthermore, gastric duplication cysts are more likely to be found in the upper abdomen, but they do not typically arise due to trauma or injury, making them an unlikely cause in this case. (B) Hemangioma liver – Incorrect: A liver hemangioma is a benign vascular lesion of the liver that can sometimes present as a mass in the abdomen. However, liver hemangiomas are more common in adults and are typically asymptomatic. They would not form as a result of trauma to the upper abdomen and would be unlikely to present as a well-defined mass in the epigastrium in this child. Additionally, a liver hemangioma would not be expected to develop so specifically in the epigastric region, as the liver is located in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. (D) Periumbilical inclusion cyst – Incorrect: A periumbilical inclusion cyst is a cyst that can form around the umbilicus, usually as a result of embryonic development issues, such as a failure in the closure of the embryonic remnant. These cysts are more likely to be located around the umbilicus, not in the epigastrium. They are usually present at birth or develop shortly afterward, rather than appearing several weeks post-injury, making them an unlikely cause for this child's symptoms.

questions.text: Most common cause of chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Alcohol The most common cause of chronic pancreatitis is alcohol consumption. Chronic and heavy alcohol use can lead to repeated episodes of acute pancreatitis, eventually causing fibrosis and damage to the pancreas over time, leading to chronic pancreatitis. Alcohol is known to be toxic to pancreatic tissue, and prolonged abuse can disrupt the normal functioning of the pancreas, resulting in persistent inflammation and pancreatic insufficiency. Alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis typically presents with abdominal pain, digestive disturbances, and malabsorption. (B) Autoimmune – Incorrect: Autoimmune pancreatitis is a less common cause of chronic pancreatitis, but it is still an important consideration in certain patients, especially those who present with unexplained pancreatic disease or elevated IgG4 levels. However, it is much less frequent than alcohol-induced chronic pancreatitis. Autoimmune pancreatitis is characterized by inflammation of the pancreas caused by the body's immune system attacking the pancreatic tissue, and it may be associated with other autoimmune conditions like IgG4-related disease. (C) Stone – Incorrect: Pancreatic stones are a known cause of chronic pancreatitis, particularly in cases of chronic obstruction of the pancreatic duct, but they are not as common as alcohol-induced pancreatitis. Stones can obstruct the flow of pancreatic enzymes, leading to inflammation and scarring of the pancreas. Pancreatic ductal stones typically develop in patients with underlying pancreatitis, and although they can contribute to chronic pancreatitis, they are less common compared to alcohol as the primary etiological factor. (D) Hereditary Pancreatitis – Incorrect: Hereditary pancreatitis is a rare cause of chronic pancreatitis. It is typically caused by genetic mutations in the PRSS1 gene, which predispose individuals to develop pancreatitis at a young age, often leading to recurrent episodes of pancreatitis and, eventually, chronic pancreatic damage. However, hereditary pancreatitis accounts for only a small fraction of cases, making it a less common cause of chronic pancreatitis compared to alcohol use.

questions.text: First investigation for a suspected case of cancer head of pancreas is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Endoscopic USG guided FNAC The first investigation for suspected cancer of the head of the pancreas is Endoscopic Ultrasound (EUS)-guided Fine Needle Aspiration (FNAC). EUS is a highly sensitive and specific imaging modality that allows detailed visualization of the pancreatic head and surrounding structures. It also enables the use of a fine needle aspiration technique to obtain tissue samples directly from the tumor. This method is the preferred approach for confirming the diagnosis of pancreatic cancer due to its high accuracy in identifying small lesions that may not be well visualized on other imaging modalities. It also avoids the need for more invasive procedures in most cases, and the tissue obtained can be used for cytological or histopathological examination. (A) Transperitoneal CT guided biopsy – Incorrect: CT-guided biopsy is a less preferred option for obtaining tissue from the pancreatic head. Although CT-guided biopsy can be effective for lesions in accessible locations, it is not the first-line choice for suspected pancreatic cancer, especially in the head of the pancreas, where the tumor may be difficult to access without the risk of complications, such as bleeding or injury to surrounding structures. EUS-guided FNAC is generally preferred due to its higher accuracy and lower complication rate in the pancreatic head region. (C) Laparotomy – Incorrect: Laparotomy is a surgical procedure and is typically not used for initial diagnosis of pancreatic cancer. It is performed when a diagnosis has already been established or if it is necessary for surgical resection.
