This class typically includes patients with severe ascites or encephalopathy, or significantly elevated bilirubin, low albumin, and high INR. Since this patient has mild ascites and no encephalopathy, and the laboratory values do not suggest severe liver dysfunction, Class C is not applicable. D. CP D – There is no Child-Pugh Class D; the system only includes Classes A, B, and C. Therefore, this option is not correct.

questions.text: CEAP score is used for
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Venous disorders The CEAP score (Clinical, Etiological, Anatomical, and Pathophysiological classification) is specifically used to classify venous disorders, particularly in the context of chronic venous disease (CVD). It is a comprehensive system used to assess the severity of varicose veins, venous insufficiency, and other related conditions. The CEAP score evaluates the clinical presentation (C), the underlying etiology (E), the anatomical distribution of the disease (A), and the pathophysiological changes (P) involved in venous disorders. This scoring system helps guide management and assess disease progression. A. Arterial disorders – The CEAP score is not used for arterial disorders. Arterial conditions, such as peripheral artery disease (PAD), are evaluated with different classification systems, like the Fontaine or Rutherford classification, which focus on symptoms, stages of disease, and severity related to arterial blood flow. C. Neurological disorders – The CEAP score is not relevant for neurological disorders. Neurological conditions are typically assessed using other classification systems based on symptoms, neurological examination findings, and imaging studies. D. Trauma – The CEAP score is also not used for trauma. Trauma management is typically based on other clinical and diagnostic systems focused on injury severity, such as the AIS (Abbreviated Injury Scale) or the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) for head injuries.

questions.text: Identify the given scalpel blade
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Blade no 11 Scalpel blade no 11 is a small, triangular blade with a sharp point and is often used for precise incisions in small, delicate areas. It is particularly useful for making stab incisions or for procedures where fine, pointed cuts are required, such as in eye surgery, biopsy procedures, or minor vascular procedures. A. Blade no 15 – Blade no 15 is smaller and has a curved edge. It is typically used for small incisions or dissection. Though it can be used for delicate work, it has a curved cutting edge rather than the sharp point seen in blade no 11, making it less ideal for pinpoint incisions. B. Blade no 10 – Blade no 10 is a larger, curved blade commonly used for general surgery procedures. It is used for making larger incisions in skin and tissue. Its curved cutting edge is not suited for the precise, pointed cuts required for some tasks, unlike blade no 11. D. Blade no 12 – Blade no 12 has a hooked shape and is typically used for curved incisions, such as those required for tonsillectomies or small excisions. It is not as precise as the sharp pointed blade no 11, making it unsuitable for tasks requiring accuracy in small, delicate cuts.

questions.text: Identify the type of knot in the given image
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Granny knot A Granny knot is an incorrect knot typically formed by tying two overhand knots in the opposite directions. This knot is not stable and tends to slip under pressure, making it unsuitable for surgical procedures. It is often the result of careless knot tying, where the two ends are tied incorrectly. The knot in the given image likely demonstrates the opposite directionality of the knot loops, which characterizes a Granny knot. B. Surgeon's knot – A Surgeon’s knot is a modified version of the square knot, with an additional twist in the first throw, making it more secure than a standard square knot. This knot is designed for use in surgery to ensure that it does not slip, unlike the Granny knot, which is prone to slipping. C. Reef knot – A Reef knot, also known as a square knot, is commonly used for tying packages, but in surgery, it is not as secure as the Surgeon’s knot. The reef knot is formed by tying two loops in the same direction, but it lacks the additional twist that provides greater security. It is generally used for non-critical applications. D. None of the above – Since the knot in the image clearly fits the description of a Granny knot, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: If a mother donates kidney to her son, this becomes an example of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Allograft An allograft refers to an organ or tissue transplant between two genetically different individuals of the same species. In this case, a mother donating a kidney to her son is an example of an allograft because they are genetically different individuals within the same species (human). Allografts are the most common type of transplant and can involve organs from living or deceased donors. A. Isograft – An isograft is a transplant between genetically identical individuals, such as identical twins. Since the mother and son are genetically different, this cannot be considered an isograft. C. Autograft – An autograft refers to a transplant where tissue or an organ is taken from one part of an individual’s body and transplanted to another part of the same body. Since the kidney is being donated from one person to another, it is not an autograft. D. Xenograft – A xenograft is a transplant between individuals of different species, such as a pig heart being transplanted into a human. Since both the donor and recipient are human, this is not a xenograft.

choices.text: Aromatase inhibitors are replacing tamoxifen in premenopausal women
Post mastectomy radiation therapy is given when 4 or more lymph nodes are +ve
Tamoxifen is not useful in post menopausal women
In premenopausal women, multidrug chemotherapy is given in selected patients

questions.text: True about treatment of early breast cancer is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Post mastectomy radiation therapy is given when 4 or more lymph nodes are +ve Post mastectomy radiation therapy is typically recommended when there are 4 or more positive lymph nodes (lymph node involvement) in order to reduce the risk of recurrence. This helps in targeting any remaining cancer cells in the area and can significantly improve outcomes in patients with high-risk features of breast cancer. The decision for radiation therapy is often based on the extent of lymph node involvement, tumor size, and other pathological factors. A. Aromatase inhibitors are replacing tamoxifen in premenopausal women – This statement is incorrect. Aromatase inhibitors are generally used in postmenopausal women, as they work by reducing the amount of estrogen produced in the body. In premenopausal women, tamoxifen is typically preferred because it blocks estrogen receptors in the breast tissue. Aromatase inhibitors are not commonly used in premenopausal women unless ovarian suppression is also being done. C. Tamoxifen is not useful in postmenopausal women – This is also incorrect. Tamoxifen is actually useful in postmenopausal women who have estrogen receptor-positive (ER-positive) breast cancer. While aromatase inhibitors are often preferred in postmenopausal women, tamoxifen can still be used, especially in cases where aromatase inhibitors are not suitable. D. In premenopausal women, multidrug chemotherapy is given in selected patients – While this is generally true, it is not specific enough to be the most accurate answer. Multidrug chemotherapy is often given to premenopausal women with high-risk or advanced breast cancer. However, the mainstay of treatment for early-stage breast cancer often includes surgery followed by hormonal therapy (tamoxifen) and/or chemotherapy, not necessarily chemotherapy alone in all cases.

questions.text: Parathyroid autoimplantation is done using which muscle
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Brachioradialis Parathyroid autoimplantation involves implanting parathyroid tissue, often after the removal of hyperplastic or abnormal parathyroid glands during surgery. The brachioradialis muscle is commonly used for this procedure because it is located in the forearm and is easily accessible for the implantation of parathyroid tissue. The muscle provides a favorable environment for the graft to survive, as it offers a good blood supply and is less likely to cause complications or rejection. A. Biceps brachii – The biceps brachii is not typically used for parathyroid autoimplantation. Although it is a prominent muscle in the upper arm, it does not provide the same advantages as the brachioradialis in terms of accessibility and blood supply for the autoimplantation procedure. B. Triceps – The triceps muscle, located at the back of the upper arm, is also not preferred for parathyroid autoimplantation. The brachioradialis offers better accessibility and a more suitable blood supply, making it a better choice compared to the triceps. D. Sartorius – The sartorius muscle is located in the thigh, and it is not typically used for parathyroid autoimplantation. The location of the brachioradialis muscle in the forearm makes it more accessible and suitable for this procedure.

questions.text: Most common indication of liver transplantation in children is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Biliary atresia The most common indication for liver transplantation in children is biliary atresia, a condition where the bile ducts are either absent or damaged, leading to liver damage and cirrhosis. Biliary atresia is a congenital disease that leads to the blockage of bile flow, resulting in jaundice, liver damage, and eventual liver failure if not treated early. Liver transplantation is often necessary when surgical procedures, like the Kasai procedure, fail or when the disease progresses to end-stage liver failure. B. Cirrhosis – Cirrhosis is a common reason for liver transplantation but is more often a result of various underlying liver diseases rather than a direct indication in pediatric cases. Cirrhosis can result from diseases such as hepatitis, metabolic disorders, or chronic cholestasis, but biliary atresia remains the most common pediatric cause of end-stage liver disease requiring transplantation. C. Hepatitis – Hepatitis can lead to liver failure and the need for a transplant, particularly chronic viral hepatitis, but it is not as common a cause of liver transplantation in children as biliary atresia. Hepatitis is more commonly a cause in adults, especially in cases of chronic hepatitis C or chronic hepatitis B, though it may be an underlying cause in pediatric cirrhosis as well. D. Drug reactions – Drug reactions can cause liver injury, but they are less common causes of liver failure requiring transplantation compared to biliary atresia. Drug-induced liver injury is typically reversible with stopping the offending agent, and only in rare cases does it lead to irreversible liver failure.

questions.text: Best graft for femoro-popliteal anastomosis is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Reverse saphenous vein graft The reverse saphenous vein graft is considered the best graft for femoro-popliteal anastomosis. It is the preferred graft because it is a autograft (taken from the patient’s own body), which reduces the risk of immune rejection and offers excellent long-term patency. When the saphenous vein is used in reverse, the valves within the vein are flipped, helping to prevent early graft failure and improving blood flow in the graft. The reverse saphenous vein graft is often the first choice for bypass procedures in the femoro-popliteal region, especially in patients with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). A. Dacron patch – A Dacron patch is a synthetic material that can be used for vascular surgeries, but it is not the preferred graft for femoro-popliteal anastomosis. It is more commonly used in arterial reconstructions when autologous veins are not available, but it has a higher risk of infection, thrombosis, and poorer long-term patency compared to saphenous vein grafts. B. Long saphenous vein graft – The long saphenous vein can be used for bypass procedures, but using it without reversing it (in its natural orientation) leads to potential issues with valvular function, which could result in poor graft patency. This is why reverse saphenous vein graft is preferred, as it addresses these issues and ensures better flow. D. PTFE graft – The PTFE graft (polytetrafluoroethylene) is a synthetic graft material used for bypass surgeries. It is not typically the first choice for femoro-popliteal anastomosis due to its increased risk of infection, thrombosis, and lower patency rates compared to autologous vein grafts. However, it may be used if there are no suitable veins available for harvesting.

questions.text: What is class 3 non-heart beating donor-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Awaiting cardiac arrest A Class 3 non-heart-beating donor (NHBD) refers to a donor awaiting cardiac arrest. This is a situation in which organ donation is planned following the cardiac death of a patient. In this case, the patient is typically in a situation where their heart is still beating but will undergo cardiac arrest, either naturally or due to a medically induced process, after which organ retrieval will occur. The aim is to procure organs for transplantation from a person after cardiac death rather than brain death. A. Unsuccessful resuscitation – This refers to a situation where attempts to resuscitate a patient have failed, and the patient is declared clinically dead. While this could potentially lead to organ donation in certain cases, it does not specifically define a Class 3 NHBD donor. This term is more related to the moment when cardiac arrest is awaited for donation, not necessarily tied to resuscitation failure. B. Dead on arrival – Dead on arrival (DOA) patients are those who arrive at the hospital with no signs of life, indicating cardiac arrest has already occurred. These patients are typically not considered for Class 3 NHBD because they are already clinically dead at the time of arrival. NHBD involves a period of cardiac arrest waiting for the appropriate moment for organ retrieval. D. Cardiac arrest while brain dead – A brain-dead patient who experiences cardiac arrest is considered a brain-dead donor under different classifications and is not categorized as a Class 3 NHBD donor. Brain death is the irreversible cessation of all brain activity, and organ donation can proceed while the heart is still beating (if supported by mechanical means). Class 3 NHBD donors are distinct as they are typically alive and awaiting cardiac arrest, not brain dead.

questions.text: A patient of 50kg with 40% burn surface area was brought to casualty. How much fluid should be given in first 8 hours-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 2 ltr

choices.text: It is absorbed by hydrolysis and protease action
It is derived from gut of cat
It is derived from gut of cattle
It used in repair of intestinal anastomosis

questions.text: Which is true about the given image-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) It is derived from gut of cattle The material in the image is likely catgut, which is a type of chromic surgical suture traditionally made from the submucosa of the small intestine of an cattle.. Despite the name "catgut," it is not derived from cats but from the intestinal tissue of cattle (and historically, sometimes sheep). Catgut is commonly used for absorbable sutures because it is slowly absorbed by the body through a process of hydrolysis and protease action, which makes it suitable for use in surgical procedures like intestinal anastomosis. A. It is absorbed by hydrolysis and protease action – While this statement is true in general for catgut and other absorbable sutures, it doesn't directly address the material's origin or its specific use as described in the question. So, while correct in its description of absorption, it doesn't answer the question about the material's source. B. It is derived from gut of cat – The term "catgut" is a misnomer, as it is not derived from cats. It is actually derived from the intestines of oxen (or sheep, though oxen are more common). Therefore, this statement is incorrect. D. It is used in repair of intestinal anastomosis – While catgut can indeed be used in the repair of intestinal anastomosis, this statement is incomplete because it doesn't answer the specific question about the origin of the material shown in the image. The focus here should be on the source of catgut, and not just its application.

questions.text: Ankle brachial index is falsely increased in-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Calcified and thickened arteries The Ankle-Brachial Index (ABI) is a simple test used to assess peripheral arterial disease (PAD) by comparing the blood pressure in the ankle to the blood pressure in the arm. In patients with calcified and thickened arteries, such as those with diabetes mellitus or chronic kidney disease, the blood vessels become stiff and non-compliant. This stiffness can lead to falsely elevated ABI values, because the pressure measurement in the ankle may be inaccurate due to the inability of the artery to compress during the cuff inflation. As a result, the ABI might suggest normal or even elevated blood flow, despite the presence of peripheral artery disease. A. Limb ischemia – Limb ischemia usually leads to a decreased ABI because reduced blood flow in the arteries of the limb will result in lower ankle pressures compared to the brachial artery pressures. This typically causes the ABI to be falsely low, not increased. C. Venous insufficiency – Venous insufficiency affects the venous system and does not directly influence arterial pressure. While it can cause swelling and other symptoms, it does not cause the false elevation of ABI. ABI is specifically used to evaluate arterial health, and venous conditions do not typically impact the result. D. Limb pain – Limb pain can occur for various reasons, including musculoskeletal pain, neuropathy, or ischemia, but it does not directly affect the accuracy of the ABI. The test is designed to assess vascular health, and pain does not generally cause false elevation of the ABI.

choices.text: Wide local excision is treatment of choice
It has more concentration of growth factors
It will not spread beyond wound site
It has more vascularity and collagen

questions.text: True about keloid-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It has more concentration of growth factors Keloids are abnormal growths of fibrous tissue that occur as a result of an overactive healing process after skin injury. They are characterized by an increased concentration of growth factors, such as TGF-β (Transforming Growth Factor Beta), which stimulates fibroblasts to produce excessive collagen. These growth factors contribute to the excessive, thickened scar tissue that extends beyond the original wound site. The overproduction of collagen and growth factors in the healing process leads to the characteristic raised, firm, and often red or purple appearance of a keloid. A. Wide local excision is treatment of choice – Wide local excision of a keloid is not the treatment of choice, as it can often result in the keloid recurring or even growing larger due to the aggressive nature of the tissue’s healing process. The goal in managing keloids is typically to prevent recurrence, so other treatment options like steroid injections, silicone sheets, or laser therapy are preferred to reduce scar formation and keloid growth. C. It will not spread beyond wound site – This statement is incorrect. Unlike normal scars, keloids can spread beyond the original wound site. They can grow into surrounding tissue, leading to a larger, raised mass, often spreading to areas that were not involved in the original injury. This feature distinguishes keloids from hypertrophic scars, which typically remain confined to the wound area. D. It has more vascularity and collagen – While it is true that keloids have increased collagen production, they are not more vascular than normal tissue. Keloids are hypovascular compared to normal skin. The increased collagen is what makes them thick and fibrous, while the vascularity is often reduced, making them look pale or less red compared to other types of scars.

questions.text: Which of the following instrument is shown in image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Morris retractor The instrument shown in the image is most likely a Morris retractor. The Morris retractor is commonly used in surgery, particularly in procedures where access to deeper tissues is required, such as abdominal or pelvic surgeries. It is characterized by its sharp, curved blades that help hold back tissue or organs, providing a clear view of the surgical area. This retracting instrument is designed to be very effective in retracting soft tissues during surgery. A. Joll – The Joll retractor is a different surgical instrument, typically used in neurosurgery or spinal surgeries. It has a distinct design compared to the Morris retractor and is used for retracting small tissues like muscles during spinal procedures. It is not the instrument in the image. C. Mayo retractor – The Mayo retractor is commonly used in abdominal surgery and is characterized by its flat, blunt ends, which are suitable for holding tissues back without causing excessive damage. However, it differs from the Morris retractor in shape and use, and it is not as curved as the instrument in the image. D. Czerny retractor – The Czerny retractor is another type of surgical retractor, commonly used in abdominal surgery to retract tissues or organs. Like the Mayo retractor, it has blunt ends, but its design differs from the Morris retractor, and it is not typically as curved.

questions.text: Size of asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm which needs active management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 55mm An asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is typically managed based on its size, as larger aneurysms are more likely to rupture. The threshold for active management, such as surgical intervention (either open surgery or endovascular repair), is generally considered to be when the aneurysm exceeds 5.5 cm (55mm) in diameter. This size has been shown to significantly increase the risk of rupture, and thus, repair is recommended to prevent life-threatening complications. Surveillance may be adequate for smaller aneurysms, but once the aneurysm reaches 55mm or more, intervention is advised to reduce the risk of rupture. A. 25mm – A 25mm aneurysm is much smaller than the threshold for surgical intervention. In general, aneurysms of this size are monitored regularly, but they do not warrant active management unless they show signs of growth or other complications. B. 35mm – A 35mm abdominal aortic aneurysm is still considered small and falls below the recommended threshold for active management. While it requires monitoring for growth, surgical intervention is not typically indicated at this size unless there are other complicating factors. D. 15mm – A 15mm aneurysm is far too small to require active management. It would typically be monitored at regular intervals, and surgical repair would not be considered unless there are concerning changes in its size or characteristics.

choices.text: Double layer repair including sub mucosa
Single layer using submucosa with lambert suture
Double layer repair using catgut suture

questions.text: Which of the following technique is used for repair of intestinal anastomosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Double layer repair including submucosa The double layer repair, including the submucosa, is the standard technique used for intestinal anastomosis. This approach is preferred because it ensures a secure and strong anastomosis, providing an additional layer of protection against leakage. The inner layer, usually made with absorbable sutures, is sutured through the mucosa and submucosa, while the outer layer is done with continuous sutures through the serosa and muscularis layer. This two-layer method enhances the integrity of the anastomosis, helping to prevent anastomotic leakage, which is a significant complication. It also promotes better healing and reduces the likelihood of complications like stricture formation. B. Single layer leaving submucosa – A single-layer anastomosis that leaves out the submucosa can be a weaker and less reliable technique compared to a double-layer repair. Omitting the submucosal layer increases the risk of anastomotic breakdown and leakage, which can lead to peritonitis and other severe complications. The submucosa provides important tensile strength, and excluding it may compromise the overall integrity of the repair. C. Single layer using submucosa with lambert suture – While the Lambert suture (which is a form of inverting suture) can be used in anastomosis, a single-layer technique using submucosa does not provide the same level of security and strength as the double-layer repair. Inverting sutures may be used for specific cases but are not ideal for general use in intestinal anastomoses, especially for more critical sites, due to their tendency to create strictures or delayed healing. D. Double layer repair using catgut suture – Catgut sutures, while historically used for intestinal anastomoses, are not the preferred choice anymore due to their rapid absorption and potential for increased inflammatory response. Absorbable synthetic sutures, such as polydioxanone (PDS) or vicryl, are now preferred due to their better tissue compatibility and longer absorption time. The focus today is on secure anastomoses with materials that provide adequate strength for longer periods of time.

questions.text: Which color of triage is given the highest priority-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Red In triage systems, the red tag represents the highest priority. This is typically assigned to patients who have life-threatening conditions but still have a chance of survival if they receive immediate medical intervention. The goal of triage is to prioritize patients based on the severity of their condition and the likelihood of survival, and those categorized as red are the ones who require immediate attention to prevent death or serious long-term disability. Common conditions that may fall under the red tag category include major bleeding, airway obstruction, or shock. A. Green – The green tag is for patients who are considered "walking wounded", meaning they have minor injuries and are unlikely to require immediate medical intervention. These patients are stable and can wait for treatment without a significant risk of deterioration, thus not the highest priority. B. Black – The black tag indicates that a patient is deceased or has injuries so severe that they are unlikely to survive, even with medical intervention. These patients are often not given further treatment as they are considered beyond help. C. Yellow – The yellow tag is assigned to patients who have serious, but not life-threatening injuries, and can wait for treatment. These patients are stable but require medical attention in due course. They are prioritized lower than the red tag patients.

choices.text: Junction between the 2nd and the 3rd part

questions.text: In a burn patient, where should the doctor be looking for the curling ulcers-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 1st part of duodenum Curling's ulcers are stress-induced gastric ulcers that commonly occur in burn patients due to the physiological stress following severe burn injuries. These ulcers typically develop in the 1st part of the duodenum, which is closest to the pyloric sphincter. This part of the duodenum is particularly vulnerable because of the decreased blood flow caused by burn-induced hypovolemia and the release of various stress-related hormones. The ulcers develop as a result of mucosal ischemia and are associated with severe burns, usually involving greater than 25% of body surface area. Monitoring the 1st part of the duodenum for potential Curling's ulcers is essential to prevent complications like perforation or gastrointestinal bleeding. B. 2nd part of duodenum – The 2nd part of the duodenum is not the typical site for Curling's ulcers. While ulcers can theoretically occur anywhere along the gastrointestinal tract, Curling's ulcers are classically found in the first part due to the stress response and altered blood flow in that region after burns. Ulcers in the 2nd part of the duodenum may arise due to other conditions like peptic ulcer disease or duodenal ulcers, but they are less commonly associated with burn trauma. C. 3rd part of duodenum – Similar to the 2nd part, the 3rd part of the duodenum is not a typical location for Curling's ulcers. This part is located further down the duodenum and is less likely to be affected by the early stages of stress-related changes caused by burns, as the 1st part is more directly involved in the early response to hypoperfusion. D. Junction between the 2nd and the 3rd part – The junction between the 2nd and 3rd parts of the duodenum is not the primary location for Curling's ulcers either. The pathophysiology of stress-induced ulcers generally leads to mucosal damage in the more proximal areas, especially the 1st part, where blood flow is most affected by the stress of burns.

questions.text: Diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bladder exstrophy Bladder exstrophy is a congenital anomaly where the bladder is exposed on the abdominal wall due to a defect in the abdominal and pelvic walls. This condition results in the externalization of the bladder, and in some cases, the internal organs like the ureters and urethra may also be exposed. It is diagnosed shortly after birth and is characterized by the protrusion of the bladder on the abdominal wall. The infant may also have a split pubic symphysis and other associated abnormalities. Surgical correction is typically needed in the early neonatal period to reconstruct the bladder and restore its function. B. Omphalocele – An omphalocele is a congenital defect where the intestines, liver, or other abdominal organs protrude into a sac outside the abdominal wall. Unlike bladder exstrophy, the organs are contained in a membrane (sac), and this condition is typically identified at birth or on prenatal ultrasound. The organs are not exposed directly to the external environment, which differentiates it from bladder exstrophy. C. Gastroschisis – Gastroschisis is another congenital abdominal wall defect where the intestines protrude outside the body through a hole in the abdominal wall, but unlike an omphalocele, there is no sac surrounding the exposed organs. In gastroschisis, the bowel is exposed directly to the environment, which makes it different from bladder exstrophy, where the bladder itself is exposed. D. Ventral hernia – A ventral hernia occurs when an organ or tissue pushes through an opening or weak spot in the abdominal wall. Unlike bladder exstrophy, a ventral hernia typically occurs after birth and is not a congenital defect like bladder exstrophy. It usually results in the protrusion of abdominal contents (often bowel) into the subcutaneous tissue, but does not involve externalization of the bladder.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with verrucous carcinoma around the glans of the penis. Examination reveals that the inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Partial penectomy Partial penectomy is the most appropriate management for a patient with verrucous carcinoma (a type of well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma) around the glans of the penis, especially when there is no involvement of the inguinal lymph nodes. Verrucous carcinoma has a slow-growing, locally invasive nature and rarely metastasizes to regional lymph nodes. The goal of treatment is to remove the tumor while preserving as much of the penis as possible to maintain function and appearance. Partial penectomy allows for complete excision of the tumor while sparing the healthy portion of the penis, making it the most appropriate surgical option in this scenario. A. Total penectomy – Total penectomy involves the complete removal of the penis and is typically reserved for cases where the tumor is extensive or involves critical structures that cannot be preserved. Since this patient has localized verrucous carcinoma and no involvement of the inguinal lymph nodes, total penectomy is too radical for this case. B. CO2 laser excision – CO2 laser excision is used for early-stage penile cancers and for lesions that are superficial and localized. However, in the case of verrucous carcinoma, the tumor may have a deep involvement of the penile tissue, which makes complete excision with a laser challenging. Laser therapy is not the first-line treatment for this condition if more extensive excision is required. C. Topical 5-fluorouracil – Topical 5-fluorouracil is used for superficial lesions, often in cases of pre-cancerous conditions like Bowen’s disease or actinic keratosis. However, verrucous carcinoma is usually a more invasive tumor, and the topical treatment would not provide sufficient tumor control in this case. Systemic treatment or more invasive surgery like partial penectomy is usually required for such lesions.

choices.text: Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids

questions.text: Identify the procedure being performed in the image given below.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Intraosseous route access for giving IV fluids The procedure shown in the image is intraosseous (IO) access, which is commonly used for the rapid administration of IV fluids, blood products, and medications when traditional intravenous (IV) access is difficult or impossible, particularly in emergency or resuscitation settings. The IO route involves inserting a specialized needle into the medullary cavity of a long bone (commonly the proximal tibia or humerus), which provides a non-collapsible venous access. This method is lifesaving in critically ill patients, especially children, where vascular collapse may make peripheral IV access challenging. A. Intraosseous cannula for pain relief – This option is incorrect. While intraosseous access can be used to administer analgesics, it is not typically placed specifically for pain relief. The primary indication is emergency vascular access for fluid and drug delivery. B. Bone marrow aspiration – This involves using a different technique and equipment to obtain bone marrow samples for diagnostic purposes, usually from the iliac crest. It is a more deliberate, sterile, and diagnostic procedure, not an emergency vascular access technique. D. Intraosseous abscess drainage – This option refers to a surgical intervention for draining pus from an infected bone, such as in osteomyelitis, and is not related to the emergency access method shown in the image.

choices.text: Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases
Urinary diversion is the next step

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with sudden onset perineal pain. O examination, foul smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue as seen in the image is noted. Which of the following is true about the given condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection The condition described—sudden onset perineal pain, foul-smelling discharge, and necrotic tissue in a diabetic patient—is consistent with Fournier's gangrene, a form of necrotizing fasciitis affecting the perineum and genital region. Fournier's gangrene is a rapidly progressive, life-threatening soft tissue infection that is polymicrobial, involving a mixed infection of aerobic and anaerobic organisms. Common pathogens include E. coli, Klebsiella, Streptococcus, Bacteroides, and Clostridium species. These organisms synergistically lead to tissue destruction, gas formation, and systemic toxicity. Early diagnosis, broad-spectrum antibiotics targeting both aerobic and anaerobic bacteria, and urgent surgical debridement are critical for survival. A. Anti-gas gangrene serum indicated for all cases – This is incorrect. Anti-gas gangrene serum (antitoxin against Clostridium perfringens) is specific to clostridial myonecrosis, not routinely used in Fournier’s gangrene, which is usually polymicrobial and not always caused by clostridia. B. Urinary diversion is the next step – This is not universally true. Urinary diversion, such as suprapubic catheterization, may be required only if the urethra is involved or access is compromised, but it is not the next immediate step. Emergency surgical debridement and broad-spectrum antibiotics take priority. C. Bilateral orchidectomy must be done – This is incorrect as well. Testes usually have a separate arterial supply from the testicular arteries (from the abdominal aorta), and may remain viable even when the scrotal wall is necrotic. Orchidectomy is only done if the testes are necrotic, not routinely.

choices.text: Parasympathetic- bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation
Sympathetic- retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction
Sympathetic- impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication following ligation of the first vessel during abdominoperineal resection for rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Sympathetic – retrograde ejaculation and bladder dysfunction The most common complication following ligation of the first vessel (usually the inferior mesenteric artery) during abdominoperineal resection (APR) for rectal carcinoma is damage to the sympathetic nerves, particularly the hypogastric plexus, which lie in close proximity to the vessel. These nerves are responsible for bladder neck closure and ejaculation mechanisms. Damage to these sympathetic fibers can result in retrograde ejaculation (where semen enters the bladder instead of being expelled) and bladder dysfunction, particularly issues with bladder emptying. This complication arises due to the disruption of sympathetic innervation, which plays a crucial role in involuntary control of urinary and reproductive functions. A. Parasympathetic – bladder dysfunction and retrograde ejaculation – This is incorrect because parasympathetic nerves (from the pelvic splanchnic nerves) are more involved in bladder contraction and erection, not bladder neck closure or ejaculation. Parasympathetic injury more commonly leads to issues with bladder emptying and erectile dysfunction, not retrograde ejaculation. B. Sympathetic – bladder dysfunction and impotence – While bladder dysfunction can be due to sympathetic damage, impotence (erectile dysfunction) is primarily mediated by parasympathetic nerves. Therefore, this combination doesn't correctly match the nerve supply affected. D. Sympathetic – impotence and loss of cutaneous sensation in perineal region – This is incorrect because cutaneous sensation in the perineum is primarily supplied by somatic nerves (pudendal nerve), and impotence is more linked to parasympathetic damage, not sympathetic injury alone.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with the lesion given in the image. He had a traumatic injury to the chest one year ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Keloid The most likely diagnosis is keloid, which is a benign fibroproliferative growth characterized by the excessive formation of scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original wound. In this case, the patient has a history of trauma to the chest, and the lesion appears as a raised, firm, nodular mass that has persisted and possibly enlarged over time — classic features of a keloid. Keloids are more common on areas such as the chest, shoulders, upper back, and earlobes, and tend to occur after skin trauma such as surgery, injury, burns, or acne. They often appear shiny and smooth and do not regress spontaneously. The delayed presentation and progressive growth of the lesion support the diagnosis. A. Hemangioma – Incorrect. Hemangiomas are vascular tumors seen more commonly in infants and young children. They usually appear as soft, compressible, red or bluish lesions and are not associated with prior trauma. Additionally, they tend to involute over time, unlike keloids. B. Hypertrophic scar – Incorrect. While hypertrophic scars also form after trauma, they are confined to the borders of the original wound and often regress over time. In contrast, keloids grow beyond the wound margins and persist or enlarge, as seen in this case. D. Neurofibroma – Incorrect. Neurofibromas are nerve sheath tumors associated with neurofibromatosis, usually presenting as soft, skin-colored nodules that may be pedunculated. They are not typically linked with trauma and do not have the dense, fibrotic appearance seen in keloids.

questions.text: A 45 year old male underwent bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair for inguinal hernia. Postoperatively, he complained of pain in the right thigh. Which of the following nerve entrapment leads to this symptom?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh (LCNT), also known as the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, is commonly at risk of entrapment during laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair, especially with mesh fixation or trocar placement near the anterior superior iliac spine. Entrapment of this nerve leads to a condition called meralgia paresthetica, characterized by pain, burning, or numbness over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. Since this nerve is purely sensory, there is no motor weakness. The symptoms described in the patient are classic for LCNT entrapment post-hernia repair. A. Ilioinguinal nerve – Incorrect. The ilioinguinal nerve supplies the skin of the superomedial thigh, root of the penis/scrotum (in males), or mons pubis/labia majora (in females). Entrapment of this nerve would typically cause groin or scrotal pain, not lateral thigh pain. B. Iliohypogastric nerve – Incorrect. This nerve provides sensation over the lower abdominal wall and upper gluteal region. Entrapment would lead to suprapubic or flank pain, not pain isolated to the lateral thigh. C. Femoral nerve – Incorrect. The femoral nerve innervates the anterior thigh muscles (motor) and provides sensory innervation to the anterior thigh and medial leg. Entrapment of this nerve would cause motor weakness of hip flexion and knee extension, along with sensory loss, not isolated sensory pain on the lateral thigh.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER following a road traffic accident. On examination, the patient opens his eyes to painful stimulus, speaks inappropriately, and withdraws his limbs to a painful stimulus. What is his GCS score?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) E2V3M4 The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is used to assess a patient's level of consciousness after head trauma. It comprises three components: Eye Opening (E), Verbal Response (V), and Motor Response (M), with scores ranging from 3 (deep coma or death) to 15 (fully awake). In this case: Eye Opening to Painful Stimulus = E2 Inappropriate Words = V3 Withdrawal from Pain = M4 Adding these scores: E2 + V3 + M4 = Total GCS score of 9 This corresponds to Option C: E2V3M4, which is the correct answer. This GCS score indicates a moderate head injury. A. E2V2M3 – Incorrect. While eye opening to pain (E2) matches, a verbal score of 2 (incomprehensible sounds) and motor score of 3 (flexion to pain/abnormal flexion) are not supported by the case. The patient speaks inappropriate words (V3) and withdraws (M4), not abnormal flexion. B. E3V3M3 – Incorrect. Eye opening to speech (E3) is inconsistent, as the patient opens eyes only to pain. Also, motor response (M3) indicates abnormal flexion, whereas the patient is withdrawing, which is M4. D. E3V2M2 – Incorrect. Eye opening to speech (E3) and verbal response (V2) do not match the case. Also, M2 implies extension to pain (decerebrate posture), which is more severe than the described withdrawal

choices.text: Angioembolization is the treatment of choice
Echinococcus species is involved in etiology

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and abdominal pain with jaundice. Investigations showed the given findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding his condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Echinococcus species is involved in etiology The most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with fever, abdominal pain, and jaundice with imaging findings suggestive of a cystic lesion in the liver is a hydatid cyst, caused by Echinococcus species, most commonly Echinococcus granulosus. This parasitic infection leads to the formation of fluid-filled cysts within the liver, which can become secondarily infected or rupture into the biliary tree, causing jaundice, cholangitis, or even anaphylaxis. The presence of daughter cysts and calcified walls on imaging is typical for hydatid disease. Diagnosis is supported by serology and imaging, and treatment often includes albendazole with or without surgery depending on the stage and complications. A. Surgery is mandatory – Incorrect. While surgery may be indicated in complicated or large cysts, it is not always mandatory. Medical management with albendazole and minimally invasive procedures (e.g., PAIR – puncture, aspiration, injection, re-aspiration) are also effective for certain types of hydatid cysts. Surgical intervention is reserved for ruptured, infected, or compressive cysts. B. Fine-needle aspiration cytology is diagnostic – Incorrect. FNAC is contraindicated in suspected hydatid disease due to the risk of cyst rupture and anaphylaxis. Diagnosis is usually made through imaging and serological tests. If aspiration is needed (e.g., PAIR), it is done under controlled conditions with pre-treatment using albendazole. C. Angioembolization is the treatment of choice – Incorrect. Angioembolization is used in vascular lesions, such as hepatic hemangiomas or bleeding tumors, not in hydatid cysts. It has no role in the treatment of Echinococcal disease.

questions.text: A 40 year old male patient presents with a swelling that has been slowly growing in the past 2 years. On examination, it was variable in consistency and fully mobile. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Parotid tumor The most likely diagnosis is a parotid tumor, given the patient’s history of a slow-growing swelling over 2 years, with variable consistency and complete mobility on examination. These features are characteristic of benign salivary gland tumors, most commonly pleomorphic adenoma, which accounts for the majority of parotid tumors. Pleomorphic adenomas are known for being painless, slow-growing, and mobile, and may feel firm or rubbery with a lobulated surface. The variability in consistency suggests a mixed tissue composition, which is also typical of pleomorphic adenomas. Their location near the angle of the mandible and mobility over underlying structures further support the diagnosis. A. Dermoid cyst – Incorrect. Although dermoid cysts can be mobile and slow-growing, they are usually found in midline locations like the suprasternal notch or near the eyebrow. They are also typically soft and doughy, rather than variable in consistency. C. Sebaceous cyst – Incorrect. Sebaceous cysts (epidermoid cysts) are firm, dome-shaped lesions with a central punctum, often fixed to the overlying skin but mobile over deeper tissues. They typically have a shorter duration, and their consistency is more uniform rather than variable. D. Cervical lymph node – Incorrect. While cervical lymph nodes can be mobile and palpable, they typically do not persist for years unless part of a chronic inflammatory or neoplastic process. They are usually firm and uniform in consistency, and may be tender if inflamed.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of alcohol dependence syndrome presents with sudden and unintentional weight loss. What is the most likely diagnosis? ALP- 240IU/L S. direct bilirubin- 1mg/dl AST/ALT- 0.5 Alpha fetoprotein- 600ng/ml
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hepatocellular carcinoma The most likely diagnosis in this case is Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC). This is supported by multiple key findings: The patient is a known case of alcohol dependence, a significant risk factor for chronic liver disease and cirrhosis, both of which predispose to HCC. The elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level of 600 ng/mL is a strong diagnostic marker, as AFP levels >400 ng/mL are highly suggestive of HCC in the appropriate clinical context. Sudden and unintentional weight loss is a classic constitutional symptom of malignancy, including HCC. The AST/ALT ratio <1 (0.5) is not typical for alcoholic hepatitis (which usually shows AST:ALT >2), and the elevated ALP and direct bilirubin are consistent with hepatic dysfunction often seen in liver tumors like HCC. A. Hepatic adenoma – Incorrect. Hepatic adenomas are benign tumors usually seen in young women, often associated with oral contraceptive use. They are not typically seen in chronic alcoholics and rarely elevate AFP. B. Cholangiocarcinoma – Incorrect. This malignancy arises from the bile ducts and is associated with obstructive jaundice, pruritus, and markedly raised ALP and bilirubin. AFP is usually not elevated in cholangiocarcinoma. D. Alcoholic hepatitis – Incorrect. Although alcohol use is a common cause, alcoholic hepatitis typically presents with AST:ALT ratio >2, modest AFP elevation (if any), and does not usually cause high AFP levels like 600 ng/mL. Weight loss may occur but is not as dramatic or abrupt as in malignancy.

questions.text: A patient presented with features of chronic pancreatitis with recurrent attacks and has a 10mm dilatation of the pancreatic duct with intraductal calculi present. Which of the following is the surgery of choice?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy The most appropriate surgery for a patient with chronic pancreatitis, recurrent attacks, dilatation of the pancreatic duct, and intraductal calculi is longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (also known as the Puestow procedure). This surgery is indicated when there is pancreatic ductal dilation with obstructive symptoms due to calculi. The procedure involves creating an anastomosis between the pancreatic duct and the jejunum, allowing for the drainage of pancreatic secretions and relieving the ductal obstruction. This helps to manage symptoms, prevent further episodes of pancreatitis, and potentially prevent further complications like pancreatic pseudocysts or chronic pain. A. Pancreaticoduodenectomy – Incorrect. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure) is typically performed in cases of pancreatic cancer or severe chronic pancreatitis involving the head of the pancreas, often with gallbladder disease or biliary obstruction. It is not indicated solely for patients with pancreatic duct dilatation and intraductal calculi without other indications like malignancy or massive organ involvement. C. ERCP and sphincterotomy – Incorrect. ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) with sphincterotomy can be used to relieve symptoms in patients with pancreatic ductal stones or strictures, but it is typically more effective in acute attacks or mild cases. This approach is not the surgery of choice when there is significant pancreatic duct dilatation and recurrent attacks, as the relief might be short-lived or incomplete for patients with chronic pancreatitis and significant ductal pathology. D. Coring of pancreas head – Incorrect. Coring of the pancreas head (removal of diseased tissue or pancreatic head resection) is not the standard approach for chronic pancreatitis with dilated ducts and intraductal calculi. While this procedure may be used in some cases of focal pancreatitis, it is less effective for diffuse disease or significant ductal dilation.

questions.text: A woman presented with BIRADS-5 breast lesion. Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for this lesion?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) ER positive A BIRADS-5 breast lesion indicates a high suspicion for malignancy, with a likelihood of cancer greater than 95%. The prognostic factors for breast cancer include several molecular and tumor markers, and among these, ER (Estrogen Receptor) positivity is considered a good prognostic factor. When a breast cancer is ER-positive, it means that the cancer cells are responsive to estrogen, which generally results in a better prognosis. ER-positive tumors tend to grow more slowly, are less likely to spread, and respond well to hormonal therapy like tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors, which reduce the risk of recurrence. A. BRCA-1 positive – Incorrect. BRCA-1 mutations are associated with a higher risk of developing breast cancer, particularly aggressive forms like triple-negative breast cancer. These tumors are often ER-negative and PR-negative, with poor prognosis. While BRCA-1 mutations increase the risk, they do not correlate with a better prognosis in the presence of a BIRADS-5 lesion. B. p53 positive – Incorrect. p53 mutations are typically found in aggressive and poorly differentiated tumors, and their presence is associated with a worse prognosis. p53-positive tumors are often more resistant to therapy and may be associated with a higher rate of recurrence. This makes p53 positivity a poor prognostic factor, not a good one. D. High Ki-67 – Incorrect. Ki-67 is a marker of cell proliferation, and a high Ki-67 index indicates rapid cell growth. High Ki-67 levels correlate with more aggressive tumors and a worse prognosis. Tumors with high Ki-67 often have higher chances of recurrence and metastasis, so a high Ki-67 index is considered a poor prognostic factor.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of chest pain shooting to the neck and interscapular region. X-ray shows a widenend mediastinum. BP is 110/90mmHg in the right upper limb and 160/100 in the left upper limb. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Acute aortic dissection The most likely diagnosis in this case is acute aortic dissection. The patient's sudden onset of chest pain, which radiates to the neck and interscapular region, coupled with a widened mediastinum on the X-ray, is highly suggestive of this condition. Aortic dissection occurs when there is a tear in the inner layer of the aorta, allowing blood to flow between the layers and causing the aorta to split or "dissect." This often leads to severe chest pain and can be associated with asymmetrical blood pressure readings in both arms, which is another significant sign here (right BP: 110/90 mmHg, left BP: 160/100 mmHg). Aortic dissection is a medical emergency and requires urgent intervention. A. Acute coronary syndrome – Incorrect. While acute coronary syndrome (ACS) also presents with chest pain, the character and radiation of the pain are different from those seen in aortic dissection. ACS typically presents with central, crushing chest pain that may radiate to the left arm, neck, or jaw. In this case, the pain described is shooting and radiates to the neck and interscapular region, which is more characteristic of an aortic dissection. Additionally, ACS would not cause the widened mediastinum or the significant BP asymmetry noted in this patient. B. Acute pulmonary embolism – Incorrect. Acute pulmonary embolism (PE) typically presents with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, and possibly hemoptysis. It is less likely to cause pain radiating to the neck or interscapular region. Moreover, PE is unlikely to cause a widened mediastinum on chest X-ray or significant asymmetry in blood pressure between the arms, which are key features pointing towards aortic dissection. D. Esophageal rupture – Incorrect. Esophageal rupture (Boerhaave syndrome) can present with severe chest pain, but the pain is typically associated with vomiting or retching prior to the onset of symptoms. This condition may lead to mediastinal emphysema or air in the mediastinum, but it would not typically present with the radiating pain seen in aortic dissection or the widened mediastinum without signs of air in the tissues. The BP discrepancy seen in this patient is also not characteristic of esophageal rupture.

questions.text: A patient presented with right hypochondriac pain. He had an episode of diarrhea 1 week prior. CT scan of the abdomen reveals a liver abscess of around 25ccs. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Medical therapy The most appropriate next step in management is medical therapy. In this case, the patient has a liver abscess, which is commonly caused by an infectious process, possibly following a prior episode of diarrhea. The initial treatment of a liver abscess often involves antibiotic therapy to address the infection, particularly if the abscess is small (like the 25cc abscess described here) and there are no signs of complications such as rupture, sepsis, or failure to respond to antibiotics. In many cases, medical therapy with appropriate antibiotics is sufficient for treating small abscesses. A. PAIR (Percutaneous Aspiration, Injection, and Reaspiration) – Incorrect. PAIR is a procedure where the abscess is aspirated and the cavity is irrigated and possibly injected with sclerosing agents. This approach is typically used for larger or more complicated abscesses, or in cases where medical therapy has failed. Since this patient has a relatively small abscess and no evidence of complications, PAIR is not the first-line treatment. B. Surgery – Incorrect. Surgery is typically reserved for patients with larger abscesses, complications like rupture or peritonitis, or those who fail to respond to medical therapy and less invasive procedures. In this case, there is no indication of surgical intervention because the abscess is small, and there is no mention of complications that would necessitate surgery. D. Percutaneous drainage – Incorrect. Percutaneous drainage is an option for abscesses that are larger or if there is failure to improve with medical therapy. While this might be considered if the abscess becomes larger or complicated, it is not the first step in management for a small, uncomplicated liver abscess.

questions.text: A 50 year old patient with a history of trauma one week back presents with confusion and ataxia. He is on treatment for alcohol dependence and his last intake was 2 weeks back. CT scan reveals the following finding. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Subdural hemorrhage The most likely diagnosis in this case is subdural hemorrhage. The patient’s history of trauma and alcohol dependence is significant, as alcohol can increase the risk of falls and trauma due to impaired coordination and judgment. Additionally, alcohol dependence can predispose to coagulation abnormalities, increasing the likelihood of bleeding. The symptoms of confusion and ataxia following a traumatic event, along with the CT finding, are consistent with a subdural hemorrhage. A subdural hemorrhage typically results from shearing forces that cause veins in the subdural space to rupture, leading to bleeding between the dura and the arachnoid layers. This type of hemorrhage often has a crescent-shaped appearance on CT scans and can cause symptoms such as confusion, ataxia, and other neurological deficits, which align with the patient's presentation. A. Extradural hemorrhage – Incorrect. Extradural hemorrhage (or epidural hemorrhage) typically results from arterial bleeding (often the middle meningeal artery) following trauma, and it typically presents as a lens-shaped (biconvex) mass on CT scan. The patient’s symptoms and the location of the hemorrhage do not align with extradural hemorrhage, and the CT findings would likely show a more convex mass with a sharp border, unlike the crescent shape of a subdural hemorrhage. C. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage – Incorrect. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage (or intracerebral hemorrhage) occurs within the brain parenchyma itself, rather than between the meninges. While this type of hemorrhage can be seen in patients with trauma, the patient's clinical symptoms and the location of the bleeding are more consistent with a subdural hemorrhage. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhages would also present with different imaging findings, typically showing a more irregular shape or mass directly within the brain tissue. D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage – Incorrect. Subarachnoid hemorrhage typically results from the rupture of cerebral aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations, and it presents with sudden-onset, severe headache (often described as the worst headache of the patient’s life). While trauma can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage, it would typically present with blood in the subarachnoid space on CT, which is usually seen as hyperdense areas around the sulci. The patient’s confusion and ataxia do not align with the typical presentation of subarachnoid hemorrhage, and the CT findings in this case suggest a subdural hemorrhage rather than subarachnoid bleeding.

choices.text: Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition.
This is a case of Meleney’s gangrene
This condition is caused by beta hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial
Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the given condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Hyperbaric oxygen has no role in the treatment of this condition. Explanation: The condition described in the question is Meleney’s gangrene, a rare and severe type of postoperative synergistic bacterial gangrene that involves rapidly progressive necrotizing infection of the skin and subcutaneous tissues. It typically occurs after abdominal surgery or trauma and is associated with extreme pain, erythema, and tissue necrosis. Management is urgent and aggressive. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) has shown benefit in the treatment of necrotizing soft tissue infections, including Meleney’s gangrene. HBOT enhances oxygen delivery to hypoxic tissues, inhibits anaerobic bacterial growth, boosts neutrophil function, and supports wound healing. Therefore, statement D is false — hyperbaric oxygen does have a role in the treatment of this condition, especially as an adjunct to surgery and antibiotics. A. Repeated radical surgery every 24 hours may be required to adequately manage this condition – Correct. Meleney’s gangrene and other necrotizing soft tissue infections require aggressive and repeated surgical debridement, often daily or every 24 hours, to remove all necrotic tissue and prevent further spread. Surgical intervention is the cornerstone of management, along with antibiotics. B. This is a case of Meleney’s gangrene – Correct. Based on the description of a severe, spreading soft tissue infection requiring repeated debridement and involving mixed organisms, the clinical picture aligns with Meleney’s gangrene. This condition typically follows surgery or trauma and is characterized by rapid spread of infection with high morbidity. C. This condition is caused by beta hemolytic streptococcus and may sometimes be polymicrobial – Correct. Meleney’s gangrene often involves beta-hemolytic streptococci, particularly Group A Streptococcus, and is frequently polymicrobial, involving anaerobes like Bacteroides and Peptostreptococcus, which act synergistically. This mixed infection contributes to the rapid tissue destruction seen in the disease.

questions.text: A patient presents with swelling in the groin region and it is diagnosed as a direct inguinal hernia. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Conjoint tendon Explanation: A direct inguinal hernia occurs when abdominal contents herniate through a weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal, specifically through Hesselbach's triangle, which is bounded by the rectus abdominis muscle (medially), the inferior epigastric vessels (laterally), and the inguinal ligament (inferiorly). The conjoint tendon (also known as the inguinal falx), formed by the fusion of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis aponeuroses, helps reinforce the posterior wall of the inguinal canal. Weakness or attenuation of the conjoint tendon allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through this wall, leading to a direct inguinal hernia. Hence, option B is correct because it identifies the structure most closely associated with the structural integrity of the area involved in direct inguinal hernias. A. Pectineal ligament – Incorrect. The pectineal ligament (Cooper’s ligament) is located on the superior ramus of the pubis and is involved in femoral hernia repair. It does not contribute to the posterior wall of the inguinal canal, so its weakness is unrelated to direct inguinal hernias. C. Reflected part of inguinal ligament – Incorrect. This is a small fibrous extension of the inguinal ligament that reflects upwards and medially toward the linea alba. It plays a minor role in the structure of the inguinal canal and does not significantly affect the strength of the posterior wall, so its weakness is not a primary factor in direct hernia formation. D. Lacunar ligament – Incorrect. The lacunar ligament forms the medial border of the femoral ring and is primarily relevant in femoral hernias. It is not part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal and thus not involved in the pathogenesis of direct inguinal hernias.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset of hematemesis. He has been taking aspirin for his arthritis and drinks alcohol occasionally. He gives a history of occasional abdominal pain. On examination, there is no abdominal mass or tenderness. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Peptic ulcer Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is peptic ulcer disease (PUD). This condition often presents with upper gastrointestinal bleeding manifested as hematemesis, especially in individuals with known risk factors. The patient has a history of aspirin use, which is a common cause of mucosal injury leading to ulcer formation due to its inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis, reducing gastric mucosal protection. Additionally, occasional alcohol consumption can irritate the gastric mucosa and exacerbate ulceration. The history of abdominal pain supports the diagnosis, as ulcers often cause epigastric discomfort. The absence of abdominal tenderness or mass does not exclude ulcer-related bleeding, as many ulcers can bleed silently until significant hemorrhage occurs. Therefore, the clinical picture is most consistent with a bleeding peptic ulcer. A. Mallory-Weiss tear – Incorrect. This condition involves a longitudinal mucosal tear at the gastroesophageal junction, typically following forceful vomiting or retching, leading to hematemesis. The absence of preceding vomiting or retching in this case makes this diagnosis less likely. B. Esophagitis – Incorrect. Esophagitis may present with mild bleeding, dysphagia, or odynophagia, but it rarely causes significant hematemesis. It is more commonly associated with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or immunosuppressed states (e.g., candida or viral esophagitis), which are not present in this case. D. Esophageal varices – Incorrect. While esophageal varices are a serious cause of upper GI bleeding, they are typically seen in patients with chronic liver disease and portal hypertension. There is no evidence of liver dysfunction in this patient, and occasional alcohol use without signs of cirrhosis or chronic liver disease makes this diagnosis unlikely.

choices.text: Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water
Continuous exposure to cement and concrete
Continuous exposure to drills and machines

questions.text: A construction worker came to the OPD complaining of white fingers. He has been working in the cement and concrete industry and has been working on heavy machinery drills, wood, and furniture polishing for 20 years. What is the most likely etiology for this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Continuous exposure to drills and machines Explanation: The most likely etiology of the white fingers in this construction worker is Hand-Arm Vibration Syndrome (HAVS), which results from prolonged and repeated use of vibrating tools and machinery such as drills, grinders, and polishers. This syndrome includes symptoms like intermittent blanching (white fingers), numbness, tingling, pain, and reduced grip strength, and it primarily affects the vascular, neurological, and musculoskeletal systems of the upper limb. The blanching, or "white fingers," especially in response to cold, is due to vasospasm similar to Raynaud’s phenomenon, and occurs because of long-term damage to the digital arteries and nerves. Given the patient’s occupational history involving 20 years of working with vibrating machinery, option D is the most accurate explanation for his symptoms. A. Candidal infection of the fingers due to continuous exposure to water – Incorrect. Candidal infections typically present as paronychia or whitish patches with inflammation, not as blanching or vascular changes like white fingers. There is no mention of moist environments or signs of infection such as swelling or redness. B. Exposure to thinners and paints – Incorrect. Exposure to solvents like thinners and paints can cause contact dermatitis or chemical burns, but these do not usually present with white fingers due to vascular changes. There is no indication of skin irritation or rash in this scenario. C. Continuous exposure to cement and concrete – Incorrect. Prolonged contact with cement and concrete can lead to skin problems such as irritant contact dermatitis or allergic dermatitis due to the alkaline nature of cement. These skin conditions typically present with dryness, redness, or cracking, not vascular symptoms like white fingers.

questions.text: A 5 year old child was admitted to the hospital for prolapsing rectal mass and painless rectal bleeding. Histopathological examination reveals enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hamartoma Explanation: The most likely diagnosis is a hamartoma, specifically a juvenile (retention) polyp, which is the most common type of rectal polyp in children and young adults. These lesions are benign, disorganized overgrowths of tissue normally found in the affected area. Clinically, they present with painless rectal bleeding and prolapse, as described in the case. On histopathology, juvenile polyps typically show dilated, cystically enlarged glands filled with mucin, often with inflammatory cells in the stroma, which aligns with the findings of enlarged and inflamed glands filled with mucin. These features are classic for a hamartomatous polyp, confirming option C as the correct answer. A. Adenoma – Incorrect. An adenoma is a neoplastic lesion with potential for malignant transformation, usually seen in older adults. Histologically, adenomas show dysplastic epithelium, not simply mucin-filled glands with inflammation. Adenomas are less common in young patients and typically not associated with prolapse. B. Choristoma – Incorrect. A choristoma is a mass of normal tissue in an abnormal location (ectopic tissue). This does not fit the clinical or histological picture, as the rectal mass in this case is made of tissue normally found in the rectum, just disorganized — which is consistent with a hamartoma, not a choristoma. D. Carcinoma – Incorrect. Carcinoma implies malignant epithelial transformation, with features such as invasion, cellular atypia, and mitotic figures. The histology here does not show dysplasia or invasion, and the clinical presentation in a 25-year-old with painless bleeding and prolapse also does not support carcinoma, which is rare at this age.

questions.text: Identify the given condition-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Trophic ulcer Explanation: A trophic ulcer, also known as a neuropathic ulcer, is caused by loss of sensation due to nerve damage, commonly from conditions like diabetes mellitus, leprosy, or spinal cord injuries. The key characteristics include painless ulceration, typically over pressure points (such as the heel, sole, or metatarsal heads), and deep, punched-out appearance with a surrounding area of callus or dry skin. These ulcers develop due to repetitive unnoticed trauma and poor wound healing secondary to lack of protective sensation. The chronic nature, absence of pain, and location over pressure points strongly point toward a trophic ulcer, making option D the correct diagnosis. A. Venous ulcer – Incorrect. Venous ulcers usually occur around the medial malleolus (ankle) and are associated with varicose veins, leg swelling, and hyperpigmentation. They are typically shallow, irregular in shape, and surrounded by edema and skin changes like lipodermatosclerosis. These features are not mentioned or implied in this case. B. Malignant ulcer – Incorrect. Malignant ulcers (e.g., Marjolin’s ulcer or ulcerating cancers) often have raised, everted edges, are non-healing, and may be associated with bleeding, foul discharge, or regional lymphadenopathy. The description lacks such suggestive malignant features or systemic signs. C. Arterial ulcer – Incorrect. Arterial ulcers typically appear on toes, feet, or other pressure areas, and are painful, with punched-out edges, and the surrounding skin is often cold, pale, and hairless due to poor arterial blood supply. The presence of pain is a distinguishing factor, which is usually absent in trophic ulcers due to neuropathy.

questions.text: A patient with varicose veins comes with complaints of eczema over the same region. What is the stage of the clinical classification according to the CEAP guidelines?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) C4a Explanation: According to the CEAP classification system for chronic venous disorders, the "C" in CEAP stands for clinical classification. C4a specifically refers to skin changes due to venous disease, including eczema (also called stasis dermatitis) and pigmentation. In this case, the patient with varicose veins presents with eczema over the same area, which is a classic skin change associated with chronic venous insufficiency. These skin manifestations are due to venous hypertension, leading to capillary leakage, hemosiderin deposition, and inflammatory responses in the skin. Therefore, C4a is the correct classification, as it directly refers to venous eczema and pigmentation without ulceration. A. C2 – Incorrect. C2 refers only to the presence of varicose veins without any associated edema, skin changes, or ulcers. Since this patient has developed eczema, the condition has progressed beyond C2. B. C3 – Incorrect. C3 denotes the presence of edema in association with venous disease, but without skin changes such as eczema or pigmentation. The presence of eczema elevates the classification beyond this stage. D. C4b – Incorrect. C4b refers to more severe skin changes, such as lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche, which are not mentioned in this scenario. Since only eczema is described, it fits within C4a, not C4b.

questions.text: A patient comes to the casualty with severe headache. His BP was found to be 160/100mmHg. CT scan revealed a subarachnoid hemorrhage. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nimodipine Explanation: The next best step in the management of a patient with a confirmed subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the administration of Nimodipine, a calcium channel blocker. Nimodipine has been shown to significantly reduce the risk of delayed cerebral ischemia and vasospasm, which are major causes of morbidity and mortality following SAH. It is typically started as early as possible after diagnosis and continued for 21 days. While it does not treat the hemorrhage itself, it plays a crucial role in preventing secondary complications and improving neurologic outcomes. Thus, initiating Nimodipine is the most appropriate and immediate pharmacological intervention after confirming SAH. B. Angiography – Incorrect. While cerebral angiography is important for identifying the source of bleeding (e.g., ruptured aneurysm), it is not the immediate next step. Stabilization and prevention of complications like vasospasm with Nimodipine take precedence before invasive investigations. C. Surgery – Incorrect. Surgical intervention (e.g., clipping or endovascular coiling of the aneurysm) is a definitive treatment but is typically done after initial stabilization and imaging to localize the source. It is not the immediate next step after the CT diagnosis, especially before administering measures to prevent vasospasm. D. Fibrinolytic therapy – Incorrect. Fibrinolytics (e.g., tPA) are contraindicated in hemorrhagic strokes, including subarachnoid hemorrhage, as they would worsen bleeding. Their use in this setting would be dangerous and is never appropriate.

questions.text: A 20 year old female patient consumed a cleaning product containing 90% sodium hydroxide. She is having complete dysphagia. What is the best step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Feeding jejunostomy Explanation: Ingestion of strong caustic agents like sodium hydroxide can cause severe damage to the esophagus, leading to complete dysphagia (inability to swallow). The best immediate management in this case, after stabilizing the patient and addressing any acute injuries (such as airway protection, fluid resuscitation, and pain management), is to establish nutritional support. A feeding jejunostomy (J-tube) is typically recommended in patients who have severe esophageal injury or strictures, and are unable to maintain oral intake due to dysphagia. It allows for enteral feeding bypassing the damaged esophagus and providing nutritional support until the patient can recover or the esophagus can be treated or repaired. This is the most appropriate step in managing long-term nutritional needs. A. Esophagojejunostomy – Incorrect. Esophagojejunostomy involves creating a direct anastomosis between the esophagus and the jejunum, which is generally used in cases where esophageal resection is performed due to severe malignancy or extensive damage. In this case, complete dysphagia due to caustic ingestion is better managed with feeding via a jejunostomy tube before considering such extensive procedures. B. Stent placement – Incorrect. Stent placement may be used for palliative management of esophageal strictures in certain situations (such as cancer or benign stenosis), but it is not the first-line treatment in the acute setting of caustic ingestion. The priority here is nutritional support and treating the esophageal injury, which stents would not address effectively in this scenario. D. Gastrojejunostomy – Incorrect. Gastrojejunostomy is typically performed in cases of gastric outlet obstruction or intractable gastric issues, and is not appropriate for managing caustic esophageal injury. The goal in this case is to bypass the damaged esophagus, and a feeding jejunostomy is a more direct and suitable approach.
